questions.text: A patient with intestinal malabsorption is found to markedly improve when flour products (bread, noodles, etc.) are removed from his diet. At the height of the patient’s disease, marked histologic changes would be seen at which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Proximal small bowel (Ref: Robbins 8th/795-796, 9/e p782-783)

 

The patient has celiac disease, which is apparently an acquired hypersensitivity to the gluten (such as gliadin) in wheat. Unlike tropical sprue (which may be related to enterotoxigenic E. coli infection), which involves the entire small bowel, celiac sprue is usually limited to the proximal small bowel.

questions.text: Single mutation in a nucleotide base changing it from protein coding to terminating codon is known as
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Nonsense mutation

 

Explanation:

  • Nonsense mutation: A tyrosine (codon, UAC) may be mutated to a termination codon (UAA or UAG) which leads to premature termination of the protein and the functional activity may be destroyed, e.g. beta-thalassemia.

Incorrect answers:

 

FALSE: Option (a) Missense mutation

 

Types and effect:

 

Missense but Acceptable Mutation: A change in amino acid may be produced in the protein and no functional consequences.

 

Mis-sense; Partially Acceptable Mutation: The amino acid substitution affects the functional properties of the protein.

 

Mis-sense; Unacceptable Mutation: The single amino acid substitution alters the properties of the protein to such an extent that it becomes non-functional and the condition is incompatible with normal life.

 

FALSE: Option (c) Frameshift mutation: This is due to addition or deletion of bases → the reading frame shifts  → a “garbled” (completely irrelevant) protein, with altered amino acid sequence is produced.

 

FALSE: Option (d) Silent mutation: A point mutation may change the codon for one amino acid to a synonym for the same amino acid.

questions.text: A 66-year-old female with deformity fell down from stairs on an outstretched hand. The following Xray was done. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Barton’s Fracture

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION B. Barton's Fracture:

  • Barton's fracture is a specific type of distal radius fracture that extends into the radiocarpal or radioulnar joint.
  • This fracture occurs when there is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius, often due to a fall onto an outstretched hand.
  • The X-ray shows a clear involvement of the radiocarpal joint, which is characteristic of Barton's fracture.

OPTION A.  Colles' Fracture:

 

  • Colles' fracture is a common wrist fracture that occurs when there is a break in the distal radius bone with dorsal (backward) displacement of the hand.
  • It typically results from a fall onto an outstretched hand, similar to the mechanism described in the case.
  • However, Colles' fracture does not involve the distal radioulnar joint, which is evident in the X-ray provided.

OPTION C.  Chauffeur's Fracture (Hutchinson's Fracture):

 

  • Chauffeur's fracture typically involves a fracture of the radial styloid process.
  • It does not typically extend into the radiocarpal joint, as seen in the X-ray.

OPTION D.  Smith's Fracture:

 

  • Smith's fracture, also known as a reverse Colles' fracture or "garden spade" deformity, involves a fracture of the distal radius with volar (forward) displacement of the hand.
  • This type of fracture typically occurs due to a fall on the back of the hand or wrist.
  • The X-ray does not show volar displacement, making Smith's fracture less likely.

choices.text: Electro larynx device

questions.text: A 43-year-old male patient of T3N0M0 carcinoma larynx has undergone total laryngectomy and has permanent tracheostomy following this surgery. The doctor suggested a device given in picture below for vocal rehabilitation. What is the name of this device?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Electro larynx device

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION C. Electrolarynx Device: This is the correct term for the device shown in the picture. An electrolarynx is a handheld device that produces sound vibrations that can be used to produce speech in individuals who have had their larynx (voice box) removed.

 

OPTION A.TEP Device (Tracheoesophageal Puncture Device): This is a device used for vocal rehabilitation in individuals who have undergone a total laryngectomy. It involves creating a small hole (puncture) between the trachea (windpipe) and the esophagus (food pipe) to allow for speech.

 

OPTION B. Pharynx Speech Device: This term is not commonly used, and there isn't a specific device known as a "pharynx speech device." Speech following laryngectomy is typically achieved through methods like TEP or the use of an electrolarynx.

 

OPTION D. Panje Device: There isn't a well-known medical device referred to as the "Panje device" for vocal rehabilitation.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man complains of widespread pruritus for the past two weeks. The itching is particularly bad at night. He has no history of note and works in the local car factory. On examination he has noted to have a number of linear erythematous lesions in between his fingers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Scabies

 

Explanation of each option:

 

OPTION B. Scabies

  • It is a parasitic infestation caused by the Sarcoptes scabei mite.
  • It typically presents with intense itching, especially at night, and can lead to linear erythematous lesions (Burrows) in between the fingers, as well as in other body folds and areas.

  • Scabies is highly contagious and often spreads through close personal contact.

Scabies:

  • It burrows into the skin, laying its eggs in the stratum corneum.

  • The intense pruritus associated with scabies is due to a delayed type IV hypersensitivity reaction to mites/eggs which occurs about 30 days after the initial infection.

Management of Scabies:

  • Permethrin 5% is first-line
  • Malathion 0.5% is second-line
  • Pruritus persists for up to 4-6 weeks post eradication

OPTION A. Fibreglass exposure

  • It is less likely to cause widespread pruritus associated with linear erythematous lesions between the fingers.
  • Exposure to fibreglass can lead to skin irritation and itching, but it is not a common cause of these specific findings.

OPTION C. Cimex lectularius infestation

  • Commonly known as bed bugs, can cause skin reactions, including itching and rash.

  • However, the linear erythematous lesions between the fingers are more characteristic of scabies.

OPTION D. Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

It is a rare disorder that typically presents with bone lesions and is not associated with the clinical findings described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with widespread pruritus, particularly worse at night, and linear erythematous lesions between the fingers (Burrows), the most likely diagnosis is scabies.

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.39-34.47

questions.text: A 29-year-old G1P0 presents to your hospital at 23 weeks gestation for an ultrasound. The ultrasound image below shows the birth defect. Which of the following is the most likely defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Encephalocele

 

Explanation for each option:

 

The ultrasound image indicates an encephalocele, which is a congenital neural tube defect where a sac-like protrusion of the brain and meninges through the skull. This condition is typically diagnosed during prenatal ultrasounds.

 

Let's briefly explain the other options:

 

OPTION A: Meningocele: This is a type of neural tube defect where only the meninges protrude through an opening in the spine or skull, without brain tissue involvement.

 

 

OPTION C: Anencephaly: Anencephaly is a severe neural tube defect where a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is absent. This condition is typically fatal shortly after birth.

 

 

OPTION D: Omphalocele: Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where some of the abdominal organs, such as the intestines or liver, protrude into a sac outside the abdomen. It is not related to the brain or neural tube

questions.text: In the context of health education and behavior change, consider a situation where a local health department in a city decided to address the rising cases of communicable diseases. They identified inadequate hand hygiene as a significant contributing factor. To address this, they organized a mass gathering to promote hand wash awareness. During this event, they employed a systematic approach to ensure maximum impact. They started by making people aware of the importance of hand hygiene, followed by sparking interest through demonstrations and interactive sessions. Subsequently, they gauged the audience's understanding and openness to the idea, and finally, they encouraged and supported the adoption of these practices in their daily routine. Based on this description, which of the following sequences of events in the behavior change process is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Awareness-interest-evaluation-adoption 

 

5 stages are included in this process –

  • Awareness
  • Interest
  • Evaluation
  • Trial
  • Adoption.

choices.text: Temperature on the left side
Proprioception on the right side
Vibration on the left side
Pain sensation on the right side

questions.text: A 30-year-old male had a road traffic accident and on evaluation, he was found to have lesion of the dorsal column on the left side of the spinal cord. Which of the following is expected to be affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vibration on the left side

  • In this patient, the dorsal column has been affected on the left side, so the sensations carried by the dorsal column on the left side will be affected
  • The sensations carried by dorsal column include soft touch, pressure, vibration sensations and position sense (proprioception)
  • Temperature and pain sensations are not carried by the dorsal column
  • The vibration sensation will be affected on the left side and proprioception will also be affected on the left side (not right side)

 

(Refer : Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, pg no : 721)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be sold only on prescription of a registered medical practitioner?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Schedule H drugs

  • According to the drugs and cosmetic act, 1940 (rules 1945), schedule H deals with the drugs which must be sold by retail only when a prescription by registered medical practitioner is produced. Most of the drugs fall under this schedule.
  • Schedule X gives the names of psychotropic drugs requiring special licenses for manufacturing and sale.
  • Schedule J deals with a list of ailments for which no drugs claim prevention or cure.
  • Schedule Y specifies requirements and guidelines on clinical trials, import and manufacture of new drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the ‘hepato-cystic’ triangle?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Cystic artery

 

The Calots triangle has been modified in contemporary literature as the area bound superiorly by the inferior surface of the liver, laterally by the cystic duct and the medial border of the gallbladder and medially by the common hepatic duct (‘hepatocystic triangle’). It is an important surgical landmark as the cystic artery usually can be found within its boundaries

 

Calot’s triangle, or the hepatobiliary triangle, is the spaces bordered by the cystic duct inferiorly, the common hepatic duct medially and the superior border of the cystic artery.

 

 

 

Reference: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1232

questions.text: The most common cause for spontaneous first trimester abortion is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chromosomal Aneuploidy

 

 

Ref: Page no. 347, William’s 25th edition

questions.text: A person feels that grains of sand are lying under the skin or some small insects are creeping on the skin giving rise to itching sensation the condition is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cocaine poisoning

 

Explanation: Please remember that Tactile hallucinations are characteristic in cocaine poisoning. The addict feel like insects (bugs) are crawling under the skin of the part of their body. He may even complain of presence of sand grain under the skin. This is often associated with excoriation of the skin. This is also called cocaine bugs/ Formication/ Magnan symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

OPTION B.  Organophosphorus poisoning: Organophosphorus compounds are found in pesticides and nerve agents. While they can cause a wide range of symptoms, including neurological effects, formication is not a prominent or typical symptom of organophosphorus poisoning.

 

OPTION C. Morphine poisoning: Morphine is an opioid analgesic, and its overdose can lead to respiratory depression, altered consciousness, and pinpoint pupils, among other symptoms. Formication is not a characteristic symptom of morphine poisoning.

 

OPTION D. Alcohol withdrawal: Alcohol withdrawal can lead to a range of symptoms, including tremors, seizures, hallucinations, and anxiety. While hallucinations can occur during alcohol withdrawal, the specific symptom of formication (feeling like insects are crawling under the skin) is not a common or classic feature of alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective

 

Chronic Cocaine Poisoning (COCAINISM/ COCAINOPHAGIA/COCAINOMANIA):

  1. The victim presents with an unstable mental condition or psychopathic tendency, which presents with manifestation, such as:
  1.  Toxic delirium
  2.  Psychotic disorder characterised by paranoid delusions, visual and tactile hallucination.
  3. Tactile hallucinations are characteristic. This is also called cocaine bugs/ Formication/ Magnan symptom
  1. Sexual and reproductive dysfunction
  2. Crack Babies: Cocaine abuse by pregnant women has been associated with an increased risk of congenital malformations in the foetus called crack babies.
  3. Tongue and teeth becomes black

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-year-old child with complaints of not growing well, On asking history, the child had a history of low birth weight. She also had feeding difficulties and poor appetite. On examination, the child has a feature of prominent forehead, small jaw and narrow chin. On examination she also had, clinodactyly. The appearance of the child is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans . A. Russell - Silver syndrome

 

Russell-Silver Syndrome

  • Most cases occur sporadically, chromosome 11p15, maternal disomy of chromosome 7.

Possible risks include:

  • Metabolic syndrome.
  • Uterine and vaginal dysgenesis
  • Gonadal hypofunction or testicular cancer in males.
  • Low muscle mass or low bone mineral density.
  • Myoclonus dystonia (in people with chromosome 7-related RSS).

 

 

Option B,C and D are not the features of Beckwith-Weidman syndrome, Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female comes to the casualty with history of severe eye pain, redness and diminution of vision. On examination the visual acuity is 6/60, there is circumcorneal congestion, corneal oedema and a shallow anterior chamber. Which is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intravenous Mannitol

 

Explanation for each option :

 

OPTION B. The patient's presentation with severe eye pain, redness, diminution of vision, circumcorneal congestion, corneal edema, and a shallow anterior chamber is indicative of acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG). AACG is a medical emergency that requires prompt management to lower intraocular pressure (IOP) and relieve symptoms. Intravenous Mannitol is the preferred initial treatment choice for AACG because it has an osmotic effect, drawing fluid out of the eye and reducing IOP rapidly.

 

Because of high IOP there’s receptor level ischemia-this precludes use of topical medications as the receptors would not respond to topical medication. That is why systemic Mannitol is the DOC in case of AACG Attack.

 

OPTION A. Atropine ointment: Atropine is a mydriatic agent (dilates the pupil) and is not the primary treatment for AACG. It may be used as an adjunct to help break the attack by dilating the pupil, but it should not be used as the sole treatment.

 

OPTION C.  Ciprofloxacin eye drops: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic eye drop used to treat bacterial eye infections. It does not address the underlying issue of increased intraocular pressure in AACG and is not the primary treatment for this condition.

 

OPTION D.  Gentamicin eye drops: Gentamicin is another antibiotic eye drop used for bacterial eye infections. Like ciprofloxacin, it does not address the elevated IOP seen in AACG and is not the primary treatment for this condition.

questions.text: All of the following structure pass through the aortic opening of diaphragm except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vagal trunk

  • The vagal trunk does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.
  • It passes through the esophageal opening at the level of T10 vertebra.

 

 

 

The aortic opening of the diaphragm is an anatomical structure that allows certain structures to pass between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

Let's discuss each option in detail:

 

Option A. Aorta:

  • It passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm as it descends from the thoracic cavity (descending aorta) into the abdominal cavity (abdominal aorta).
  • This is a significant passage, as it allows the aorta to continue its course into the abdomen.

Option B. Azygous Vein:

  • It drains blood from the posterior thoracic and abdominal walls.
  •  It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the superior vena cava.
  • This allows for the return of blood from the posterior part of the body to the superior vena cava and then into the right atrium of the heart.

Option C. Thoracic Duct:

  • It is responsible for draining lymph from the lower half of the body and the left upper half of the body.
  •  It also passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the thoracic cavity and eventually drain into the venous circulation.

Option D. Vagal Trunk (Incorrect):

  • The vagal trunks refer to the vagus nerves, specifically the right and left vagus nerves (cranial nerves X).
  • These nerves are responsible for various functions in the body, including regulating heart rate, gastrointestinal activity, and respiratory functions.

While the vagus nerves do extend into the thoracic cavity, they do not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm. Instead, they enter the abdomen separately

questions.text: An eight-year-old child presented with headache, high fever, and features of meningismus. She has a history of going for a summer vacation in a pool resort. Within 3 days, her condition deteriorated.  What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Naegleria fowleri

 

History of contact in swimming pool with features of meningitis that is fatal in a three days period is suggestive of free-living amoeba infection due to N. fowleri.

 

Naegleria fowleri:

  • It is also called Brain-eating amoeba.
  • Infection is acquired while swimming in contaminated water
  • Amoeboid trophozoite enters through nasal mucosa  and enters the brain
  • It causes primary amoebic meningoencephalitis which is very fatal, and the patients die within a week
  • Wet mounts of CSF show motile amoeboid trophozoites
  • Treatment : Amphotericin B

 

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker`s Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No 499.

questions.text: Which one of the following agent sensitizes the myocardium to catecholamines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Halothane

 

Explanation of each option:

 

OPTION B. Halothane:

  • Halothane is another volatile anesthetic agent. Unlike isoflurane, halothane can sensitize the myocardium to catecholamines. This means that when halothane is administered, the myocardium becomes more responsive to catecholamines like adrenaline (epinephrine) and norepinephrine, which can lead to increased heart rate and contractility.

OPTION A. Isoflurane:

  • Isoflurane is a volatile anesthetic agent used in surgery. It does not sensitize the myocardium to catecholamines.

OPTION C. Propofol:

  • Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic agent commonly used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia. It does not sensitize the myocardium to catecholamines.

OPTION D. Ether:

  • Ether is a historical anesthetic agent that is rarely used today. It does not sensitize the myocardium to catecholamines.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

 

Halothane is the agent that sensitizes the myocardium to catecholamines, potentially leading to increased heart rate and contractility when catecholamines are present. This effect can have implications for the cardiovascular response during surgery or anesthesia.

questions.text: A 67-year male with history of chronic smoking hemoptysis with cough. Bronchoscopic biopsy from centrally located mass shows undifferentiated tumor histopathologically. Most useful I.H.C. (immunohistochemical) marker to make a proper diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cytokeratin (Robbins 10th/ 720)

  • The presence of chronic smoking, cough and hemoptysis in old man is a pointer towards a diagnosis of bronchogenic cancer. The central location suggests the possibility of a squamous cell cancer.
  • Robbins writes “Histologically, this tumor is char­acterized by the presence of keratinization and/or intercellular bridges”.

Other options with the associated conditions are as follows

  • HMB is a marker of melanoma,
  • Hep par1 is a marker of liver cancer
  • Parvalbumin is a marker of schizophrenia

questions.text: How many ATPs are produced by oxidation of one acetyl CoA via TCA cycle:
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  10 ATP

 

Explanation:

  • Three molecules of NADH and one of FADH2 are produced for each molecule of acetyl-CoA catabolized in one turn of the cycle.

 

Incorrect answers:

 

False: Option (a, c, d): are wrong.

choices.text: Deviated nasal septum

questions.text: 8yr old child presents with snoring and mouth breathing. On examination he had an elongated face with dull expression, open mouth, high arched palate, prominent and crowded upper teeth and hitched up upper lip. Most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Adenoid hypertrophy

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION C. Adenoid hypertrophy: Adenoid hypertrophy is a common condition in children and can lead to snoring, mouth breathing, and a characteristic facial appearance with the symptoms described in the patient. Enlarged adenoids can obstruct the nasopharynx, leading to the clinical features observed.

 

OPTION A. Deviated nasal septum: Deviated nasal septum can cause nasal obstruction, but it typically does not result in the specific facial and dental characteristics described in the patient, such as the elongated face, high arched palate, prominent and crowded upper teeth, and hitched up upper lip.

 

OPTION B. Hypertrophied turbinates: Hypertrophied turbinates can contribute to nasal obstruction, but they also do not explain the full range of symptoms and facial features mentioned.

 

OPTION D. Nasal polyps: Nasal polyps are soft, noncancerous growths that can develop in the nose or sinuses. While they can contribute to nasal congestion and difficulty breathing through the nose, they do not typically cause the specific facial and dental findings mentioned in the patient.

choices.text: Multiple system atrophy type C

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman was hospitalized at week 10 of gestation because of severe hyperemesis. At admission the patient appeared restless and confused . The blood investigations revealed serum sodium 107 mmol/L and serum potassium 1.1 mmol/l. Active and simultaneous correction of these were performed, but the patient deteriorated further. MRI was done and shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Osmotic demyelination syndrome

 

Osmotic demyelination syndrome, previously known as central pontine myelinolysis (CPM), is a neurological disorder characterized by the demyelination in the central nervous system. It often occurs when serum sodium levels are rapidly corrected in individuals with severe hyponatremia, as was the case in this patient with severe hyperemesis during pregnancy.

 

The MRI image provided shows a characteristic bright signal in the central pons on T2-weighted imaging, indicating demyelination. This radiological finding is consistent with ODS.

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION A: Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder characterized by copper buildup in the body and can present with neurological symptoms, but it wouldn't typically result from the rapid correction of sodium levels.

 

OPTION C: Multiple System Atrophy Type C, is not the correct diagnosis. Multiple System Atrophy (MSA) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by autonomic dysfunction and motor symptoms. Type C refers to cerebellar involvement in MSA, but it does not present with the specific clinical and radiological findings seen in ODS.

 

OPTION D:  Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP), is also a neurodegenerative disorder but presents with different clinical features, such as supranuclear gaze palsy and postural instability, which were not described in the case.

questions.text: A 53-year-old female with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with increasing shortness of breath, fatigue, and swollen ankles over the past few months. She has a decreased exercise tolerance and has noticed waking up at night feeling short of breath. On examination, her blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg, heart rate 98 bpm, and she has jugular venous distension, a displaced apex beat, and bibasilar crackles in her lungs. An echocardiogram shows an enlarged left ventricle with a reduced ejection fraction of 35%.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dilated Cardiomyopathy

 

Explanation:

  1. Dilated Cardiomyopathy (Answer A): The patient’s symptoms of shortness of breath, fatigue, swollen ankles, and decreased exercise tolerance are consistent with heart failure. The echocardiographic findings of an enlarged left ventricle and a reduced ejection fraction of 35% are characteristic of dilated cardiomyopathy. This form of cardiomyopathy leads to systolic dysfunction, where the heart's ability to pump blood is decreased. The patient's history of hypertension and diabetes are significant risk factors for this condition.
  2. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Answer B): This condition typically presents with asymmetric left ventricular hypertrophy and often a preserved or even increased ejection fraction. The patient’s echocardiogram does not support this diagnosis.
  3. Restrictive Cardiomyopathy (Answer C): Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by stiff ventricular walls that impair diastolic filling, usually with a normal ejection fraction. The echocardiogram findings in this case do not suggest restrictive cardiomyopathy.
  4. Acute Myocardial Infarction (Answer D): While an MI can lead to heart failure symptoms, the patient’s presentation and echocardiographic findings are more chronic in nature and indicative of a dilated cardiomyopathy rather than an acute event.

questions.text: During a workshop on epidemiological methods, a resident asks the mentor about understanding the metrics that assess the performance of diagnostic tests. The mentor explains that 'prevalence' of a disease in a population has a direct impact on certain diagnostic test measures. Considering this background and the interplay of prevalence with these metrics, which among the following diagnostic test measures is directly influenced by the prevalence of a disease in a given population?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Positive predictive value

 

Explanation - 

 

Positive predictive value (PPV) is directly proportional to Prevalence

 

 PPV α Prevalence

questions.text: The MTOCs are associated with the protein, which is involved in the process of cell division?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tubulin

  • Centrosomes are cellular organelles, which are located near the nucleus in the cytoplasm of eukaryotic cells.
  • They are made up of two centrioles and amorphous pericentriolar substances.
  • The centrosomes are microtubules organizing centers (MTOCs) that contain gamma-tubulin and have a significant role in cell division.
  • When a cell replicates (cell cycle), centrosomes duplicated themselves
  • After duplication, the pairs move away to the poles of the mitotic spindles and monitor the stages of cell division

 

(Refer: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 40)

choices.text: Corticosteroids facilitate the action of β- agonists.
Corticosteroids sensitize adenosine receptors to xanthine’s.
Direct bronchodilator action of corticosteroids.

questions.text: A known asthmatic, presented to the emergency with severe exacerbation not relieved by Salbutamol. The patient was given corticosteroids and aminophylline. What is the rationale of giving corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Corticosteroids facilitate the action of β- agonists.

  •  
  • Corticosteroids are potent anti-inflammatory agents that can help to reduce airway inflammation and improve asthma symptoms. They are a key component of the management of acute asthma exacerbations and are often administered early in the treatment course.
  • Corticosteroids provide permissive action for the functioning of catecholamines. The mechanisms for use include:
    • Decrease in inflammatory cell recruitment and activation.
    • Upregulation of beta 2-receptors.
    • Decrease microvascular permeability.
    • They may decrease mucus production.
       
  •  
  • Corticosteroids do not sensitize adenosine receptors. Increasing adenosine receptor activity would exaggerate bronchospasm, inflammation, and mucus secretion.
  • Steroids have no direct action in causing bronchodilation.
  • Increase in mucociliary clearance would not be the primary mechanism for using it in an acute exacerbation of asthma, as that is mediated by intense bronchospasm, irritation/inflammation, and edema of bronchial walls.

questions.text: A female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done from the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hysterosalpingography

  • This is an image of a Hysterosalpingogram (HSG)
  • An HSG is used to
    • Delineate uterine anomalies.
    • Endometrial cavity lesions like polyps, adhesions
    • Tubal patency in infertility

Other Options

  • Option A: Hysteroscopy appears like this image. Using fluid media to distend the uterine cavity, a hysteroscope can visualize the inside of the uterine cavity.

  • Option B: Saline infusion sonography: This is an ultrasound-based investigation, wherein saline is injected in the uterine cavity and this helps detect intra-uterine space occupying lesions and appears like this:

 

  • Option D: Transvaginal ultrasound. This appears like this:

 

Ref: Page no 588, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with respiratory distress, vomiting and cyanosis after every feeding. Examination reveals froth from nose. Which is the most common type of trachea-esophageal fistula?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Type C

  • Insults acting during gastrulation  –  when cells are told what to do and where to go – may cause multiple anomalies, e.g. VACTERL syndrome (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal, renal and limb anomalies) and CHARGE syndrome (coloboma, heart defects, choanal atresia, growth retardation, genital anomalies and ear anomalies).
  • Anatomical variations occur in tracheoesophageal fistula with or without oesophageal atresia. In Type C, the upper pouch ends in the neck or upper chest but occasionally it reaches the fistula where muscle fibres are shared. This is the most common type.

 

Diagnosis: A nasogastric tube coiled in the upper oesophageal pouch on a chest radiograph suggests the diagnosis

 

Treatment: Surgical reconstruction

 

 

Reference: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 266

choices.text: Ring fracture of base of skull
Hinge fracture of base of skull

questions.text: The image below is?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Hinge fracture of base of skull

 

Explanation: Image shows a transverse fracture of the base of the skull that completely splits it and divide it into two halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge (‘nodding face’ sign).

 

Other options

 

Option A) Ring fracture of base of skull often seen in the skull, where the bone breaks in a circular pattern around foramen magnum. The picture above have a transverse fracture that completely splits it making it a hinge fracture, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C) Comminuted fracture of skull: is when two or more intersecting lines of fracture divide the bone into three or more fragments resembling a spider web or mosaic pattern this is not the case in this picture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option D) Depressed fracture of skull: When a portion of fractured bone is driven inwards to a distance equivalent to the thickness of the skull table, it is known as depressed fracture. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective

 

‘Hinge’ # (also called Motorcyclist #):

  • linear fracture passes across the middle cranial fossa, separating the skull base into Ant and post halves,
  • Occurs Severe Force to side of head (e.g. in motorcycle accidents).
  • Such fractures are commonly associated with injuries of the brain stem, especially pontomedullary tears.

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, Anil Aggrawal, 2016, page 239

questions.text: A mother brings her child very often to the hospital. As you start noticing the child, the child is always admitted with the history of respiratory infections. So, you plan to do a complete evaluation. The X ray image appears as the following. You suspect it to be an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in dynein protein. The triad of the condition consists all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Situs solitus

 

 Kartagener's syndrome is a rare, autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder comprising the triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. The basic problem lies in the defective movement of cilia, leading to recurrent chest infections, ear/nose/throat symptoms, and infertility.

 

Option A, C and D are the triad of Kartagener's syndrome.

 

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition –Chapter - 433 Page No-From 9606

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presented with sudden diminution of vision in right eye. The fluorescein angiography revealed a picture as shown below. A diagnosis of central serous retinopathy was made. The optical coherence tomography (OCT) image is shown. Which of the retinal layers is indicated by the arrow in the photograph?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Retinal pigment epithelium

 

Explanation:

 

In central serous retinopathy (CSR), there is a detachment of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). The arrow in the optical coherence tomography (OCT) image is pointing to the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) layer. This separation of the neurosensory retina from the RPE can lead to the accumulation of subretinal fluid, causing symptoms such as sudden diminution of vision.

questions.text: Identify the splint shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Aeroplane splint

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION C .The "aeroplane" splint used for fractures of the surgical and anatomic necks of the humerus, gunshot wounds of the shoulder involving the joint, and wounds of the outer end of the clavicle and spine of the scapula. Maintains shoulder in abduction at 90 degrees and elbow flexion at 90 degrees. Useful in Erb's Palsy, Rotator Cuff repairs, post-operative shoulder and arm surgery

 

OPTION B. Braun's Bohler splint, is a medical device used in the conservative management of fractures of the lower limb. It is designed to immobilize and provide traction to the injured limb.

 

 

OPTION A. Cock-up splint is useful to restore mobility to fingers after injury, burns, radial nerve palsy, spastic wrist-drop, tendon repair.

 

 

OPTION D. "Dennis Brown Splint" is used in the treatment of clubfoot, a congenital condition where a baby's foot is turned inward.

questions.text: A 31-year-old lady presents complaining of facial discolouration. She is 26 weeks pregnant. So far it has been an uncomplicated pregnancy. On examination she has a large, flat, symmetrical, brown-pigmented patch across her cheeks, forehead, nose, and upper lip as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Melasma

 

Explanation of each option:

 

OPTION B. Melasma, also known as chloasma or "mask of pregnancy,"

  • It is a common condition that occurs during pregnancy and is characterized by the development of symmetric, brownish patches on the face, particularly on the cheeks, forehead, nose, and upper lip.

  • It is related to hormonal changes and sun exposure and is a benign condition.
  • Melasma typically occurs in pregnant women and individuals with a family history of the condition.

OPTION A. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

  • It can present with a variety of skin manifestations, including a malar rash (butterfly rash) on the face.
  • However, the malar rash in SLE is typically more erythematous (red) than brown and is often associated with other systemic symptoms.
  • It is less likely in the absence of systemic symptoms and with a presentation of a large, flat, brown-pigmented patch.

OPTION C. Polymorphic eruption of pregnancy

  • It is also known as pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy (PUPPP), is characterized by itchy urticarial papules and plaques that can occur during pregnancy.

 

  • It is different from the described pigmented patch on the face.

OPTION D. Rosacea

  • It is a chronic skin condition that primarily affects the face and is characterized by redness, visible blood vessels, and sometimes papules and pustules.
  • It does not typically present as a large, flat, brown-pigmented patch.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

 

In a pregnant woman with a large, flat, symmetrical, brown-pigmented patch on the face, the most likely diagnosis is melasma.

 

 

References: 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Page no 88.10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1119-1121

choices.text: Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm
Inability to abduct the shoulder
Weak flexion of arm at shoulder joint
Inability to extend the arm at shoulder joint

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was admitted with complaints of acute pain in the right shoulder of three-days duration associated with swelling and he also had difficulty in using his right shoulder since then. Pain was sudden at onset, continuous, and moderate to severe in intensity and it was aggravated on activity. In addition, he had severe night and rest pain. He also gave a history of intramuscular injection of Iron in the right deltoid region 2 weeks previously, which was administered in a local clinic. On examination, there was a globular swelling in the lateral aspect of the right arm extending up to the scapular region. There was a local rise of temperature and tenderness over the swelling, painful restriction of the right shoulder movements and he could not abduct his arm to the right angle. MRI scan of the right shoulder showed pyomyositis of the posterior belly of the right deltoid muscle with central abscess formation. Which among the following is not a possible complication that can be expected in this case if untreated?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Loss of sensation on lower lateral aspect of arm

  • In this case, the intramuscular injection injured the axillary nerve.
  • Axillary nerve gives rise to upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm which supply upper lateral aspect of arm not the lower lateral aspect of arm.
  • Upper lateral aspect of arm is also known as “Regimental badge area”.  If axillary nerve is damaged “Regimental badge anesthesia” occurs.
  • Axillary nerve supply to the deltoid & teres minor.

Option B. Axillary nerve supply to the deltoid muscle which is abductor of shoulder.

 

Option C. The anterior fibres of deltoid flex the arm at shoulder joint.

 

Option D. The posterior fibres of deltoid assist extension of arm at shoulder joint.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh 3rd edition, pg. 89

questions.text: A 38-year-old man patient with HIV infection presented with oral thrush and throat infection. A preliminary Gram staining of the throat swab shows Gram positive budding yeast cells. What is the culture medium shown in the image that is suitable in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sabouraud's dextrose agar

 

The above image shows SDA with fungal growth. SDA is primarily used for the selective cultivation of yeasts and moulds. SDA (Saboraud's dextrose agar) is used to grow fungus. It contains chloramphenicol which inhibits bacterial growth.

 

Other options:

  • Chocolate agar – It is mainly used for fastidious organisms requiring growth factors like factor X and factor V. Eg: Haemophilus influenzae
  • MacConkey agar – Used mainly to differentiate lactose fermenting and non-lactose fermenting colonies. Most commonly used in urine culture. Its constituents are 

P - Peptone water


L - Lactose


A - Agar


N - Neutral Red (Indicator)


T - Taurocholate

  • Loeffler's serum slope – Selective medium for C. diphtheriae

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No 87.

questions.text: Which of these Laryngeal mask airways is most preferred for use in daycare anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Proseal LMA

 

Explanation:

 

Proseal laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a re-usable second-generation supraglottic airway device. It is not a disposable device. Its parts consist of an integrated bite block, a drainage tube to remove gastric secretions, and a well sealing cuff design. This reduces the risk of aspiration. It is suitable in non-supine positions (e.g., lateral, prone), laparoscopic surgery (e.g., cholecystectomy, gynaecological surgery), and in patients who are obese.

 

Thus is the preferred choice in day care anesthesia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to his family physician because of complaints of blood in his stool and intermittent constipation. Fecal occult blood testing is positive. A colonoscopy is performed, revealing a large adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid colon. As the tumor was removed, a researcher tested the tumor and identified a mutation of RAS gene. Of the following, what was one mechanism by which the tumor developed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Abnormal GTPase activity

  • Normally, inactive RAS binds to GDP and the presence of growth factor causes GDP to be exchanged by GTP causing RAS activation. The activated RAS binds to its farnesyl transferase receptor causing increased activation of MAP kinase and promoting mitogenesis.
  • The activated RAS comes back to its normal inactive state due to the intrinsic GTPase activity which gets augmented due to a group of proteins called GTPase Activating Proteins (or GAP).
  • Mutated RAS proteins bind to GAP without augmentation of GTPase activity resulting in uncontrolled mitogenesis and tumor formation.
  • Point mutations of RAS family genes constitute the most common type of abnormality involving proto-oncogenes in human tumors.
  • 90% of pancreatic adenocarcinomas, 50% of colon, endometrial, and thyroid cancers and 30% of lung adenocarcinomas contains RAS mutation

 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 286

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with fatigue, irritability, and confusion. He reports a history of a diet primarily consisting of polished rice for several months. Physical examination reveals bilateral lower extremity weakness and sensory loss. Laboratory tests show a decrease in erythrocyte transketolase activity. Which of the following nutritional deficiencies is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Beriberi

 

Explanation of each option:

 

OPTION B: Beriberi: Beriberi is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine is essential for several metabolic pathways, including those involving glucose metabolism. In beriberi, the lack of thiamine impairs various cellular processes, including transketolase activity, which can affect energy production and lead to neurological and cardiovascular symptoms.

 

OPTION A: Pellagra: Pellagra is caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Niacin deficiency primarily affects the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and nervous system. It leads to symptoms like dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Erythrocyte transketolase activity is not typically inhibited in pellagra.

 

OPTION C: Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency. Vitamin C is necessary for collagen synthesis and wound healing. While scurvy can lead to various symptoms, including gum disease and skin changes, it does not directly inhibit erythrocyte transketolase activity.

 

OPTION D: Rickets: Rickets is caused by vitamin D deficiency or impaired vitamin D metabolism, leading to problems with calcium and phosphorus metabolism and bone mineralization. Erythrocyte transketolase activity is not typically affected by rickets.

questions.text: A patient presented with intermittent swelling and pain in the Submandibular region aggravated while taking sour food. What does the following image shows?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Submandibular calculus

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION B.

  • Calculi may form in the ducts of Submandibular or parotid glands. They are formed by the deposition of calcium phosphate on the organic matrix of mucin or cellular debris.
  • The presenting feature is intermittent swelling of the involved gland, and pain due to obstruction to outflow of saliva. Sometimes, stone is visible at the duct opening or can be palpated.
  • About 80% of the stones are radio-opaque and can be seen on appropriate X-rays and CT scan.

 

OPTION A. Submandibular abscess: A submandibular abscess would typically present with more severe and persistent symptoms, including a fever, localized swelling, and pain, along with signs of infection, such as redness and warmth. It might also require drainage.

 

OPTION C. Sialectasis: Sialectasis typically refers to the dilatation of a salivary duct and is often associated with a salivary duct obstruction, such as the presence of a calculus or stone. It doesn't provide a specific diagnosis.

 

OPTION D. Submandibular sialadenitis: Submandibular sialadenitis is an infection of the submandibular salivary gland and is often associated with pain, swelling, and warmth in the affected area. However, the imaging findings here are more suggestive of a calculus than acute infection.

questions.text: For which of the following paediatric musculoskeletal deformity Ponseti’s Technique is used :
questions.solution:
Ans. A. CTEV

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION A. CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus): Ponseti's Technique is used to treat CTEV, commonly known as clubfoot. This congenital musculoskeletal deformity involves the abnormal positioning of the foot, where it is turned inward and downward. Ponseti's Technique is a non-surgical method that involves a series of manipulations and casting to gradually correct the foot's position. It is highly effective in treating clubfoot.

 

OPTION B. Rickets: Rickets is a condition caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to weakened and softened bones. While it is a musculoskeletal disorder, Ponseti's Technique is not used to treat rickets. Treatment for rickets typically involves vitamin D supplementation and dietary adjustments.

 

OPTION C.  Congenital Vertical Talus: Congenital Vertical Talus is a rare congenital foot deformity where the foot is dorsiflexed and turned outward. Ponseti's Technique is not typically used to treat this condition. Surgical interventions may be necessary to correct congenital vertical talus.

 

OPTION D. Congenital Metatarsus Adductus: Congenital Metatarsus Adductus is a deformity where the front part of the foot turns inward. Ponseti's Technique is not the primary method used to treat this condition. It may involve stretching exercises and sometimes casting or bracing, but it is not the standard treatment as it is for clubfoot (CTEV).

questions.text: A 54-year-old male with a history of liver cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis C infection is admitted to the hospital with worsening abdominal distension and discomfort. He has a known history of ascites and has been managed with spironolactone and furosemide. On examination, his abdomen is distended with a positive fluid wave test, and he has peripheral edema. His blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, heart rate 102 bpm, and he appears slightly disoriented. Laboratory tests reveal hypoalbuminemia and elevated creatinine. A diagnostic paracentesis is performed, indicating no signs of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The patient is diagnosed with hepatorenal syndrome (HRS).In addition to standard care for HRS, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment to add for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Octreotide and albumin

 

Explanation:

  • Octreotide and albumin (Answer A): In the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS), the combination of vasoactive drugs like octreotide, which can reduce splanchnic vasodilation, and albumin, which can expand plasma volume, is beneficial. This combination is often used in HRS to improve renal function and manage the complications associated with liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension.
  • Tolvaptan (Answer B): While tolvaptan, a vasopressin V2-receptor antagonist, can be used in managing hyponatremia associated with cirrhosis, it is not the first line of treatment for HRS.
  • Midodrine and albumin (Answer C): Midodrine, an alpha-adrenergic agonist, is also used in the management of HRS. However, octreotide is often preferred in combination with albumin for its effectiveness in splanchnic vasoconstriction.
  • Intravenous furosemide (Answer D): Diuretics like furosemide are typically used in managing ascites, but they are not the treatment of choice for HRS, especially in the presence of renal dysfunction.

questions.text: Dr. Mehta, a renowned ophthalmologist in Delhi with over 25 years of experience, is conducting a seminar on visual impairments and their global implications. She emphasizes the importance of standardized definitions to facilitate international collaboration, research, and policy implementation. She mentions the World Health Organization's criteria for categorizing visual impairments. If a patient were to be classified as "blind" as per the WHO, their visual acuity, even after the best possible correction, in which scenario would warrant this classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. <3/60 in better eye

 

‘Blindness’ is defined as visual acuity of less than 3/60, or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10°, in the better eye with the best possible correction.

 

 

(PL+: Perception of Light; PL–: No perception of light)

questions.text: A 55-year-old man came with urinary symptoms of increased frequency and hesitation. The patient was diagnosed with benign hyperplasia of prostate. Which of the drugs will help to prevent further growth and possibly reduces the size of the prostate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Finasteride

  • Tamsulosin- It is an α1A-antagonist. It decreases smooth muscle tone of prostate and bladder neck which leads to improved urine flow. It is thus used for dynamic action i.e. to control the symptoms. It does not reduce the size of prostate.
  • Prazosin: It is a non-selective α1A as well as α1B/1D receptor antagonist. It can also decrease the symptoms of BPH. Its major adverse effect is postural hypotension.
  • Finasteride: It is a 5-alpha reductase (type II) inhibitor. It prevents conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. DHT is the main androgen in the prostate which is produced from testosterone by 5 a reductase and causes growth and differentiation in the prostate. Type 2 isoform of this enzyme is expressed by stromal cells in the prostate. Reduction in levels of DHT prevents further growth and sometimes reduces the size of prostate as well.
  • Testosterone: It will increase the growth of prostate.

Note: Tadalafil has been by FDA for BPH. It is a PDE-5 inhibitor. Treatment with PDE-5 inhibitors can be considered in patients who have erectile dysfunction and mild or moderate symptoms of BPH.

choices.text: Occurs due to gradual slowing of blood flow and desiccation of tissues
The black colour is due to iron sulphide formation from hemoglobin
Requires urgent debridement / amputation

questions.text: A poorly controlled diabetic patient presented with the following picture. There was crepitus on palpation. All the following statements are true about this condition except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Occurs due to gradual slowing of blood flow and desiccation of tissues

 

Explanation- This is a case of wet gangrene. Gradual slowing of blood flow and dessication is seen in dry gangrene.

 

Gangrene refers to the death of macroscopic portions of tissue, which turns black because of the breakdown of haemoglobin and the formation of iron sulphide. It usually affects the most distal part of a limb because of arterial obstruction (from thrombosis, embolus or arteritis).

  • Dry gangrene occurs when the tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of the blood stream; it is typically the result of atheromatous occlusion of arteries. 
  • Wet gangrene occurs when superadded infection and putrefaction are present. Crepitus may be palpated as a result of infection by gas-forming organisms, commonly in diabetic foot problems, and should be considered a surgical emergency with urgent tissue debridement or amputation required.

questions.text: Best method to deliver nuchal arms in breech?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lovset’s method

 

Assisted Breech Delivery:

  • In breech delivery assistance may be required for:
  1. Delivery of head
    •  Burns-Marshall method
    • Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit method
    • Piper’s forceps or Neville-Barnes forceps
  2. Extended legs
    • Pinard’s maneuver (Remember: P for popliteal fossa and P for Pinard maneuver)
  3. Extended arm
  • Lovset’s maneuver

 

Sometimes the head rotates posteriorly, so that the face is behind the pubis. Delivery in this position is difficult and ‘Prague maneuver’ may be tried.

  • Best time for episiotomy in breech
    Climbing of perineum.
  • Best time for episiotomy in vertex
    Crowning of head.

 

Ref: Page no 329  JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a long-standing history of asthma presents to the clinic with worsening respiratory symptoms. She reports increased coughing, production of brownish mucus plugs, and episodes of wheezing that have become more frequent and severe over the past few months. Her asthma medications seem less effective than before. She also mentions intermittent episodes of low-grade fever. A chest X-ray reveals fleeting infiltrates, and a high-resolution CT scan of the chest shows central bronchiectasis. Laboratory tests indicate elevated serum IgE levels and positive specific IgE and IgG antibodies against Aspergillus fumigatus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA)

 

Explanation:

  • Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA) (Answer C): The patient's history of asthma, coupled with her symptoms of cough, brownish mucus plugs, and worsening respiratory function, suggests ABPA. This condition is an allergic response to the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus, commonly seen in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis. The diagnosis is supported by the presence of fleeting pulmonary infiltrates, central bronchiectasis on CT, elevated total serum IgE, and specific antibodies against Aspergillus.
  • Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) (Answer A): While COPD can cause chronic respiratory symptoms and is associated with a history of smoking, it does not typically present with the specific immunological findings or the bronchiectasis seen in ABPA.
  • Cystic Fibrosis (Answer B): Cystic Fibrosis could present with similar respiratory symptoms and is a risk factor for ABPA, but the patient's age and the absence of a history of cystic fibrosis make it less likely.
  • Pulmonary Tuberculosis (Answer D): Although tuberculosis can cause cough and fever, the specific findings of elevated IgE levels and positive Aspergillus antibodies, along with the patient's asthma history, are more indicative of ABPA.

The combination of asthma exacerbation, characteristic radiologic findings, and specific immunologic test results strongly points to ABPA as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A mother from non-endemic area for hypothyroidism brings her child with failure to thrive, delayed development of milestones, hoarse cry, mottling of skin with the following facial and abdominal features. What is the most common cause of the child’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid dysgenesis

 

The clinical features and the image of a baby with umbilical hernia, large tongue and hypotonia are suggestive of Congenital hypothyroidism, the most common cause of Congenital hypothyroidism is Thyroid dysgenesis.

 

Untreated case may lead to

  • Intellectual disability
  • Disproportionate stature
  • Delayed bone maturation and
  • Delayed puberty.

Option A -Thyroid dyshormonogenesis is associated with positive family history in Congenital hypothyroidism cases.

 

Option C - Hashimotos thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in adolescents.

 

Option D - Graves disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism in adolescents.

 

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 581 Page No- 11398-11423

Ghai Essential Pediatrics 8th Edition, Page No-516-519.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a high fever of 103°F (39.4°C), chills, severe headache, and muscle aches. He also complains of persistent cough and shortness of breath. He recently returned from a hiking trip in the Rocky Mountains. On examination, his heart rate is surprisingly low at 55 bpm despite the high fever. His respiratory rate is elevated, and chest auscultation reveals crackles in the lower lobes bilaterally. A chest X-ray shows a bilateral interstitial infiltrate. Laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the observed Faget sign?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Legionnaires' Disease

 

Explanation:

  • Legionnaires' Disease (Answer D): The combination of high fever with relative bradycardia (Faget sign), respiratory symptoms, recent travel history (potential exposure to contaminated water systems), bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray, and elevated liver enzymes is suggestive of Legionnaires' disease. Legionnaires' disease is a type of pneumonia caused by Legionella bacteria, often associated with contaminated water sources.
  • Influenza (Answer A): While influenza can cause high fever and respiratory symptoms, it is less likely to present with Faget sign or the specific radiographic findings described here.
  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (Answer B): This is a tick-borne illness that typically presents with a rash, fever, and history of tick exposure. The pattern of symptoms and the absence of a rash make it less likely in this case.
  • Pneumonia (Answer C): While pneumonia could explain the respiratory symptoms and infiltrates on chest X-ray, Faget sign is more characteristic of specific types of pneumonia like Legionnaires' disease.

The presence of Faget sign, along with the patient's symptoms, travel history, and radiographic and laboratory findings, point towards Legionnaires' disease as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Coexistence of peripheral venous thrombosis with visceral carcinoma is known as ?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trousseau's syndrome

 

Deep venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism are the most common thrombotic conditions in patients with cancer. Migratory or recurrent thrombophlebitis may be the initial manifestation of cancer. Nearly 15% of patients who develop deep venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism have a diagnosis of cancer. The coexistence of peripheral venous thrombosis with visceral carcinoma, particularly pancreatic cancer, is called Trousseau's syndrome.

 

Trousseau's sign - seen in hypocalcemia

 

 

Ref: Harrison's 21st edition page no 726

questions.text: All the given statements are causative factors for increase in Q angle except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tight Medial patellar retinaculum

  • Q angle or the patellofemoral angle is the angle between quadriceps femoris muscle & patellar tendon. Q angle is formed by a line drawn from the ASIS to central patella and a second line drawn from central patella to tibial tubercle.

  • An increased Q angle is a risk factor for patellar subluxation.
  • Normally, Q angle is 14 degrees for males and 17 degrees for females.
  • Increase or decrease in Q angle is associated with increased peak patellofemoral contact pressures.
  • The natural tendency of lateral displacement of patella is counteracted by the insertion of vastus medialis & medial patellar retinaculum to medial border of patella.
  • On the other hand, a tight lateral patellar retinaculum will increase Q angle.

Incorrect answers:

 

Option A. Genu valgum will increase the Q angle.

 

Option B. Short iliotibial band will cause tibia to be held in an externally rotated position thereby, moving the tibial tubercle laterally and increasing Q angle.

 

Option D. Flat foot causes internal rotation of the tibia and increases the Q angle.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and lower limb, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, pg. 297

questions.text: A 40-year-old sexually active male presents to an STD clinic with painful genital sores as shown in the image below. He reports that the lesion appeared about two weeks ago and has been progressively worsening. On examination, you observe multiple painful bleeding ulcers with unilateral unilocular painful suppurative inguinal bubo. There are no other visible lesions, and the patient denies any systemic symptoms. He had multiple sexual partners in recent months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Chancroid (Soft chancre)

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION C. Chancroid (Soft chancre):

  • Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It presents with painful genital ulcers and painful suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo), as described in the scenario.
  • The ulcers are often described as "soft" (as opposed to the "hard" chancre of syphilis) and can bleed easily.
  • This fits the patient's presentation perfectly.

OPTION A. Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection:

  • HSV typically presents as painful vesicles that can rupture to form ulcers.
  • The key difference is that the inguinal lymphadenopathy seen in HSV (if present) is typically bilateral and not as dramatically painful or suppurative as that in chancroid.
  • Differentiating features between Herpes genitalis & Chancroid:

  • Moreover, the course of the lesion and the presence of multiple painful ulcers fit chancroid better than HSV.

OPTION B. Syphilis (Primary Stage):

  • The primary lesion of syphilis is the chancre, which is a solitary, painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders.
  • The patient's presentation of multiple painful ulcers with a painful inguinal bubo does not fit the primary syphilis picture.

OPTION D. Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale):

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, donovanosis typically presents as painless, beefy-red ulcers that bleed easily. They can progress to cause destruction of genital tissue.
  • While there are similarities in the ulcer presentation between chancroid and donovanosis, the painful and suppurative inguinal bubo described in the case is more characteristic of chancroid.

Educational Objective:

 

In a sexually active individual with painful genital sores, multiple painful bleeding ulcers, and a unilateral unilocular painful suppurative inguinal bubo, the most likely diagnosis is Chancroid (Option C).

 

 

References: 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.21

Online Resource:

https://www.uptodate.com/contents/chancroid?source=search_result&search=chancroid&selectedTitle=1~47

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the barium swallow shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Caustic stricture

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION B:  Caustic Stricture:

  • Caustic strictures of the esophagus result from the ingestion of corrosive substances, such as strong acids or bases and usually present as long segment strictures as seen here.
  • They can cause significant damage to the esophagus, leading to the formation of scar tissue that can narrow the esophageal lumen.
  • Symptoms may include dysphagia, chest pain, and a history of caustic ingestion.
  • This condition is associated with chemical injury to the esophagus.

 

OPTION A: Fibrovascular Polyp:

  • A fibrovascular polyp is a rare benign tumor that can occur in the esophagus. It is typically a pedunculated growth, meaning it has a stalk-like structure. It will present as a filling defect on barium swallow.

OPTION C:  Reflux Esophagitis:

 

Reflux esophagitis is a condition in which stomach acid and contents flow back into the esophagus, leading to inflammation and irritation of the esophageal lining. It will present as a short segment stricture in the mid-esophagus.

 

 

OPTION D: Esophageal Carcinoma:

  • Esophageal carcinoma refers to cancer of the esophagus, and it is associated with irregular narrowing with shouldering on barium swallow, described as “rat tail” appearance.

choices.text: 5' to 3' DNA polymerase activity

questions.text: A researcher is studying DNA polymerase fragments and their activities. When analyzing the Klenow fragment, which of the following characteristics is lacking in its enzyme activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5' to 3' exonuclease activity

 

Explanation:

 

The Klenow fragment lacks 5'-3' exonuclease activity because it is a portion of the DNA polymerase I enzyme from Escherichia coli that has been enzymatically cleaved to remove the 5'-3' exonuclease domain. This cleavage results in two fragments: the large fragment, which includes the 5'-3' polymerase activity, and the small fragment, which includes the 3'-5' exonuclease activity.

 

 

The Klenow fragment is primarily used for DNA synthesis (polymerization) in molecular biology applications. It is often employed in techniques like DNA sequencing and DNA labeling, where the main goal is to synthesize new DNA strands by adding nucleotides in the 5'-3' direction. The removal of the 5'-3' exonuclease activity makes the Klenow fragment suitable for these applications because it prevents the fragment from degrading or proofreading the newly synthesized DNA strands by removing nucleotides from their 5' ends. This lack of exonuclease activity allows researchers to control the DNA synthesis process more precisely.

Resection of the intercostobrachial nerve causes loss of sensation over the medial aspect of the upper arm. The intercostobrachial nerve is the lateral cutaneous branch of the second intercostal nerve.

choices.text: Inferior vena cava
Superior vena cava

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inferior vena cava

  • Inferior vena cava has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation.
  • Fetal heart pumps large quantity of blood into the placenta for exchange of substances.
  • From placenta, the umbilical veins collect the blood, which has more oxygen and nutrients.
  • Umbilical vein passes through liver, some amount of blood is supplied to liver from umbilical vein, large quantity of blood is diverted from umbilical vein into the inferior vena cava through ductus venosus.
  • Liver receives blood from portal vein also.
  • In liver, the oxygenated blood mixes slightly with deoxygenated blood and enters the right atrium via inferior vena cava.
  • From right atrium, major portion of blood is diverted into left atrium via foramen ovale. Foramen ovale is an opening in intra-atrial septum.
  • Blood from upper part of the body enters the right atrium through superior vena cava. From right atrium, blood enters right ventricle.
  • Then, blood is pumped into pulmonary artery. From pulmonary artery, blood enters the systemic aorta through ductus arteriosus.
  • Only a small quantity of blood is supplied to fetal lungs. Blood from left ventricle is pumped into aorta.
  • Fifty percent of blood from aorta reaches the placenta through umbilical arteries.

 

Mixing potentially occurs at 4 sites:

  1. Left umbilical vein (Oxygen saturation ~80%) – Portal vein (Much bypassed by ductus venosus to Inferior Vena cava)
  2. Left umbilical vein – Inferior vena cava – Portal vein (Oxygen saturation of IVC blood is ~65%)
  3. Superior vena cava – Right atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale)
  4. Pulmonary veins – Left atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus)

questions.text: The image given below with stages are found in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. ROP

 

Explanation:

 

Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) is a potentially blinding eye disorder that affects premature infants. ROP occurs when the developing blood vessels in the retina, the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye, are interrupted. The severity of ROP can vary, and it is classified into several stages based on its progression:

  1. Stage 1 ROP:
    • Stage 1 ROP is the earliest and mildest form of the condition.
    • In this stage, there is a demarcation line between the vascularized and avascular retina.
    • Many infants with stage 1 ROP spontaneously improve without treatment.
  2. Stage 2 ROP:
    • Stage 2 ROP is characterized by the appearance of a ridge of tissue.
    • This ridge represents the border between the vascularized and avascular areas of the retina.
    • Like stage 1, many infants with stage 2 ROP may improve on their own without intervention.
  3. Stage 3 ROP:
    • Stage 3 ROP signifies the progression to more severe disease.
    • In this stage, abnormal blood vessels begin to grow (neovascularization) from the retina into the vitreous gel inside the eye.
    • These new vessels are fragile and can lead to retinal bleeding, scarring, and retinal detachment.
  4. Stage 4 ROP:
    • Stage 4 ROP indicates a partially detached retina.
    • The abnormal blood vessels can cause traction on the retina, leading to its detachment.
    • This stage often requires surgical intervention to reattach the retina.
  5. Stage 5 ROP:
    • Stage 5 ROP is the most severe stage and represents a total retinal detachment.
    • In this stage, the entire retina is detached from the back of the eye.
    • Vision is usually severely impaired or lost in affected eyes.

 

 

 

The management of ROP depends on its stage and severity. Not all infants with ROP require treatment, as many cases resolve spontaneously without intervention. However, more severe stages (3, 4, and 5) may require laser therapy or cryotherapy to ablate the abnormal blood vessels and prevent further progression.

 

Regular eye examinations by a pediatric ophthalmologist are crucial for premature infants at risk of ROP. Early detection and appropriate management are essential to minimize the risk of vision impairment or blindness due to this condition.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to the psychiatrist with concerns about her appearance. She reports that she believes her nose is severely deformed and that everyone around her is constantly staring at it. Her family and friends have reassured her multiple times that her nose appears normal, but she remains convinced that it is a significant defect. She spends hours each day looking in the mirror, comparing her nose to pictures of others, and researching surgical options. She has even stopped attending social events due to her fear of being judged. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Body dysmorphic disorder

 

Explanation of each option:

 

OPTION A: Body dysmorphic disorder: The patient's preoccupation with a perceived defect in her appearance, despite reassurances from others, presence of repetitive behaviours such as looking in mirror along with the significant distress and impairment in her daily functioning, are consistent with the diagnosis of body dysmorphic disorder.

 

OPTION B: Body-focused repetitive behavior disorder: This disorder is characterized by recurrent behaviors focused on one's body, such as hair-pulling (trichotillomania), or skin-picking (excoriation). The patient's symptoms do not align with this disorder, as her primary concern is a perceived defect in her appearance rather than engaging in repetitive behaviors.

 

OPTION C: Delusional disorder: Delusional disorder involves the presence of one or more delusions that persist for at least one month, without other psychotic symptoms. This patient presents with a preoccupations followed by repetitive behaviours in relation to that preoccupation, this goes more in favour of body dysmorphic disorder. In case the patient develops a firm, fixed belief, even then, the diagnosis of body dysmorphic disorder with absent insight/delusional belief will be favoured over the diagnosis of delusional disorder

 

OPTION D:  Social anxiety disorder: Social anxiety disorder is characterized by a persistent fear of social situations due to concerns about being judged or humiliated. While the patient does avoid social events, her avoidance is primarily driven by her perceived appearance defect, making body dysmorphic disorder the more accurate diagnosis.

 

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE :

 

Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) is a behavior disorder characterized by an obsessive focus on perceived flaws or defects in one's physical appearance. These perceived flaws are often minor or not noticeable to others.

 

Symptoms of BDD include:

  1. Preoccupation with physical appearance: Individuals with BDD often spend hours each day thinking about their perceived flaws.
  2. Belief that the perceived flaw makes them ugly or deformed: Even if others reassure them that there's nothing wrong or the flaw is minor, they may remain convinced that it's significant.
  3. Engaging in repetitive behaviors: These can include mirror checking, excessive grooming, skin picking, or seeking reassurance from others about their appearance.
  4. Avoidance: People with BDD might avoid social situations or photos to prevent others from seeing their perceived flaws.
  5. Need for frequent cosmetic procedures: Individuals might seek out numerous cosmetic procedures to "fix" their perceived defects, but are often not satisfied with the results.
  6. Significant distress or impairment: The preoccupations cause significant distress and can interfere with social, occupational, or other areas of functioning.

questions.text: A 25-year primi with preeclampsia and fetal distress underwent an emergency LSCS. Following delivery of the baby, this was the appearance of the uterus. What could have been the reason for fetal distress?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Abruptio Placenta

 

Explanation

 

This is Couvelaire uterus. It is seen following concealed abruption and is the appearance of the uterus during a cesarean section. Points about Couvelaire uterus:

  • Also called as uteroplacental apoplexy
  • Seen in severe concealed abruption
  • Occurs due to intravasation of blood into uterine musculature
  • The uterus appears dark bluish like a bruise
  • The blood may also seep into the leaves of the broad ligament, in the ovaries or in the peritoneal cavity.
  • It is not an indication for an hysterectomy.

 

Ref: Page no 753, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The test being performed is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Finkelstein sign

 

d. Finkelstein's Sign: This test is used to diagnose De Quervain's tenosynovitis, a condition affecting the tendons on the thumb side of the wrist. The patient makes a fist with the thumb placed inside the fingers. The examiner then ulnar deviates the wrist. Pain over the tendons on the thumb side of the wrist during this maneuver is considered a positive Finkelstein’s sign.

 

a. Tinel's Sign: This test is used primarily to detect irritated nerves. It's commonly performed by tapping over the nerve to elicit a tingling sensation or pain in the distribution of the nerve. For example, Tinel's sign is often used in the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome, where tapping over the median nerve at the wrist may produce tingling in the thumb, index, and middle fingers.

 

 

b. Froment's Sign: This sign is used to test for ulnar nerve palsy. The patient is asked to hold a piece of paper between their thumb and index finger. The examiner then tries to pull the paper away. A positive Froment’s sign is indicated by the patient flexing the thumb's interphalangeal joint to hold the paper, suggesting weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle, which is innervated by the ulnar nerve.

 

 

c. Jeanne’s Sign: Similar to Froment's sign, Jeanne’s sign is another test for ulnar nerve palsy. It is characterized by hyperextension of the thumb’s metacarpophalangeal joint when the patient is making a fist or gripping something, indicating weakness in the muscles controlled by the ulnar nerve.
