questions.text: Antibiotic used for ESBL [Extended spectrum B lactamase] producing Klebsiella infection is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Carbapenem

  • Extended-spectrum B-lactamase (ESBL) producing Klebsiella infections are resistant to many beta-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins, cephalosporins, and monobactams.
  • Carbapenems are the drugs of choice for the treatment of ESBL-producing Klebsiella infections.
  • Carbapenems such as imipenem, meropenem, and ertapenem are broad-spectrum antibiotics that are effective against a wide range of Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria, including ESBL-producing Klebsiella.
  • Aztreonam, a monobactam antibiotic, Spectinomycin and streptomycin are not effective against ESBL-producing Klebsiella infections.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man visits his primary care physician with complaints of joint pain and stiffness in his knees, especially in the morning and after physical activity. He reports that over the past few years, he has noticed a gradual decrease in the range of motion in both knees. The pain is localized, and there is no significant swelling or redness in the affected joints. He has a history of playing football in his younger years and has also been overweight for several years. During the examination, the physician observes that the patient has crepitus on knee movement. X-rays of the knees reveal joint space narrowing and the presence of osteophytes. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteoarthritis

 

Explanation of each option:

 

OPTION C: Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease that commonly affects weight-bearing joints, such as the knees. It often presents with gradual onset joint pain, stiffness, and decreased range of motion. Crepitus (a crackling or grating sound with joint movement) is a common feature. The X-ray findings of joint space narrowing and osteophytes are characteristic of osteoarthritis, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

 

 

OPTION A: Gout: Gout is characterized by the sudden onset of severe joint pain, often affecting the big toe. It is caused by the buildup of uric acid crystals in the joints, leading to acute inflammation and swelling. The patient's gradual onset of joint pain, absence of significant swelling or redness, and X-ray findings are not consistent with gout.

 

GOUT KNEE

 

OPTION B: Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune condition that typically affects multiple joints symmetrically. It often presents with morning stiffness, joint swelling, and tenderness. The X-ray findings of joint space narrowing and osteophytes are not typical of rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

OPTION D: Psoriatic arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis is associated with psoriasis and can affect various joints, including the knees. It typically presents with joint pain, swelling, and skin lesions (psoriasis). While psoriatic arthritis can cause joint space narrowing, it is less common than osteoarthritis, and the absence of skin lesions makes it less likely in this case.

questions.text: A patient of Prinzmetal’s angina is started on isosorbide mono nitrate. What is the mechanism of action of nitrates in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Endothelium independent coronary vasodilatation

 

Isosorbide mono nitrate releases NO, causing coronary vasodilatation.

 

Prinzmetal (Variant/Vasospastic angina) is the type of episodic angina that is due to coronary artery vasospasm which temporarily reduces blood flow to heart, producing ischemia, thereby causing pain. It responds promptly to Nitrates and CCBs. which reverse and inhibit coronary vasospasm causing relief in pain.

 

Mechanism of action of nitrates in Prinzmetal angina:

 

When metabolized, organic nitrates release NO, that binds and activates guanylate cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to an increase in intracellular levels of cGMP, which through dephosphorylation of MLCK (myosin light chain kinase) leads to vascular smooth muscle relaxation causing vasodilatation of Epicardial coronary arteries.

 

Vasodilation can be Endothelium dependent: Vascular smooth muscle relaxation by the production of endogenous NO (EDRF) from arginine using eNOS present within vascular endothelial cells.

 

Endothelium independent: Vascular smooth muscle relaxation through the release of NO from NO donors e.g., nitrates. These drugs act directly on vascular smooth muscle to cause relaxation.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the point from A to C in the given flowchart depicting the natural history of a disease?
questions.solution:
Aus. B. Lead time

 

Lead time is defined as the interval between the point a condition is detected through screening and the Time it would normally have been detected due to appearance and reporting of signs and symptoms.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intermediate filaments

 

The clinical scenario given here describes alcoholic hepatitis. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies and they contain intermediate filaments.

 

i) Hepatocellular necrosis:

 

ii) Mallory bodies or alcoholic hyaline:

 

These are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions found in swollen and ballooned hepatocytes. They represent aggregates of cytoskeletal intermediate filaments (prekeratin). They are best seen with connective tissue stains such as Masson's trichrome and chromophobe aniline blue, as well as immunoperoxidase methods.

 

Mallory bodies are highly suggestive of, but not specific for, alcoholic hepatitis, as they can be found in a variety of other conditions, including primary biliary cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis, cholestatic syndromes, Wilson's disease, intestinal bypass surgery, focal nodular hyperplasia, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

iii) Inflammatory response: primarily polymorphs with some scattered mononuclear cells.

 

iv) Fibrosis: Pericellular and perivenular fibrosis that appears web-like or chickenwire-like. This is also termed as creeping collagenosis.

questions.text: A Pregnant woman in third trimester complains of hearing her own sounds. Examination of the ear shows movements of tympanic membrane synchronous with respiration and especially exaggerated when nostril on the contralateral side is occluded. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Patulous Eustachian tube

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION B. Patulous Eustachian tube:

  • Patulous Eustachian tube is a condition where the Eustachian tube, which connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx, remains constantly open (A normal eustachian tube stays closed and only opens during swallowing, yawning, chewing, etc.). This can result in various symptoms, including hearing one's own sounds (autophony) and sometimes a clicking sound during swallowing or breathing.

OPTION A. Eustachian tube obstruction:

  • This would typically result in difficulty equalizing ear pressure, leading to symptoms like ear fullness or discomfort during changes in altitude (e.g., when flying or driving in the mountains).

OPTION C. Otitis media with effusion:

  • This condition involves fluid accumulation in the middle ear, often due to inflammation or infection. It can cause hearing loss and a feeling of ear fullness but is not typically associated with autophony.

OPTION D. Otosclerosis:

  • Otosclerosis is a condition where there is abnormal bone deposition near the stapes foot plate area on the medial wall of middle ear, which can lead to hearing loss, especially in the form of conductive hearing loss. It is not associated with autophony.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with Hodgkin lymphoma undergoes 3 sessions of radiotherapy. Microscopic examination in the field of radiation reveals numerous acidophilic bodies and small cells with pyknotic nuclei. Which of the following proteins most likely played a key role in triggering radiation-induced cell death in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. p53

  • Apoptosis detects and destroys cells that harbor dangerous mutations, thereby maintaining genetic consistency and preventing the development of cancer.
  • p53 is the responder by which the cell recognizes genomic abnormalities and “assesses” whether they can be repaired.
  • If the damage to DNA is so severe that it cannot be repaired, the cascade of events leading to apoptosis is activated, and the cell dies.
  • p53 activates proteins that arrest the cell in G1 of the cell cycle, allowing time for DNA repair to proceed. It repair is successful, the cell survives and if DNA damage cannot be repaired, p53 activates mechanisms that terminate in apoptosis.

questions.text: In a meeting of global health experts, strategies to quantify the impact of diseases on societies are being debated. One metric, in particular, is emphasized, which combines both the years of life lost due to premature mortality and the years of life lived with disability to provide a holistic view of the disease's impact. By integrating these components, it offers a more comprehensive representation of the total health loss in populations. Which of the following measures accurately describes this combined assessment of a disease's burden on a community?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. DALY

 

Explanation - 

 

DALY or Disability Adjusted Life Years = YLL+YLD =Years Lost to Life + Years Lived with Disability.

 

It tells us about the disease burden in the society.

 

Other Options - 

 

HALE (Health Adjusted Life Expectancy) Life expectancy-DALY of all diseases. It is an indicator of the overall health status of the country.

 

QALY or Quality Adjusted Life Years tells us about the number of quality years gained in life because of an intervention.

 

Sullivan Index is similar to HALE but applies at an individual level. It tells us about the number of years a person will spend in good health free from disease or disability.

questions.text: A mother brings her Five days old baby with a birth weight of 2.5kg for follow up. On examination the child was alert and active, icterus is noted. On measuring the baby weight it was found to be 2 kg, stools is of yellow color. What is the likely cause responsible for the icteric change in the child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Breast feeding jaundice

 

As mentioned in the scenario the baby lost its 500gmas of weight because of dehydration as a result of infrequent breast feeding and is known as Breast feeding jaundice.

 

Option A- In case of Physiological jaundice there will be a negligible weight loss.

 

Option B - Breast milk jaundice results from the lipoprotein lipase enzyme present in the breastmilk, not because of the infrequent breast feeding.

 

Option D- In case of Cholestatic jaundice conjugated bilirubin will be increased and the color of stools will be changed.

questions.text: A 22-year-old presents with hepatomegaly and neurological symptoms. Lab tests reveal decreased serum ceruloplasmin and elevated urinary copper. Which gene is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. ATP7B

 

Explanation:

 

The diagnosis is Wilson's hepatolenticular degeneration which is an inherited autosomal recessive condition. This disease is caused by a mutation in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a copper-transporting P-type ATPase in cells, which is required for excretion of copper from cells. So, copper is not excreted through bile, and hence copper toxicity.

  • Increased copper content in hepatocyte inhibits the incorporation of copper to apo-ceruloplasmin. So ceruloplasmin level in blood is decreased.
  • Clinical Features
    • Accumulation in liver leads to hepatocellular degeneration and cirrhosis.
    • Deposits in brain basal ganglia leads to lenticular degeneration and neurological symptoms.
    • Copper deposits as green or golden pigmented ring around cornea; this is called Kayser-Fleischer ring.
       
  • Treatment consists of a diet containing low copper and injection of D-penicillamine, which excretes copper through urine. Since zinc decreases copper absorption, zinc is useful in therapy.

Incorrect Options:

 

A) ATP7A is associated with Menkes disease, a rare X-linked recessive disorder characterized by copper deficiency due to impaired copper transport.

 

C) MTP (Microsomal Triglyceride Transfer Protein) is associated with abetalipoproteinemia, a disorder affecting lipid metabolism.

 

D) CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) is associated with cystic fibrosis, a genetic disorder affecting the respiratory and digestive systems.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is IOL implantation after cataract surgery contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION D. Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (JIA): JIA is a form of arthritis that affects children. In cases of JIA, especially when there is active inflammation or a history of severe eye involvement (e.g., uveitis), IOL implantation may be contraindicated due to the increased risk of postoperative complications and the potential for ongoing eye inflammation. Careful evaluation and consultation with both rheumatologists and ophthalmologists are essential in such cases to assess the risks and benefits of IOL implantation. In some instances, an alternative approach, such as contact lenses or glasses, may be considered for vision correction after cataract removal in patients with JIA-associated eye conditions.

 

OPTION A. Psoriatic arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that affects some individuals with psoriasis. It is not typically a contraindication for IOL implantation after cataract surgery.

 

OPTION B.  Reiter's syndrome: Reiter's syndrome is a form of reactive arthritis that can occur in response to certain infections. It does not usually contraindicate IOL implantation.

 

OPTION C. Fuch’s heterochromic iridocyclitis: Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis is a chronic, low-grade, non-granulomatous anterior uveitis. It can lead to complicated cataract development, and patient usually presents with decreased vision due to cataract. It does not usually contraindicate IOL implantation.

questions.text: A cattle rearer presents to the ER with 2-day history of fever, malaise and a painless black eschar on his right forearm. On examination, the eschar is necrotic with surrounding erythema and edema. Culture was done which on gram staining revealed the following finding. Identify the bacteria responsible for the patient’s presentation.
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Bacillus anthracis

 

The patient’s history – Cattle rearer, painless black eschar and the culture findings showing bacteria arranged in chains giving a bamboo stick appearance – is highly suggestive of Anthrax. The bacteria responsible for anthrax is Bacillus anthracis.

 

The clinical presentation of anthrax can be of two types –

  1. Cutaneous anthrax which is also called as Malignant Pustule or Hideporter’s disease.
  2. Pulmonary anthrax which is also called Woolsorter disease characterized by Hemorrhagic Mediastinitis

Selective media – PLET agar

 

It is a category A bioterrorism agent.

 

Special identification features for B. anthracis are as follows:

  1. Bamboo stick appearance - GPB with central spores
  2. M`Fadyean`s reaction - capsular stain by polychrome methylene blue
  3. Medusa head appearance in blood agar
  4. Inverted Fir tree appearance in Gelatin stab culture
  5. String of Pearls reaction in solid medium

 

 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No 571.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs inhibits neutrophil recruitment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Colchicine

 

Colchicine is primarily used to treat gout and familial Mediterranean fever. One of its mechanisms of action is the inhibition of neutrophil migration into inflamed tissues, thereby reducing inflammation. It disrupts the microtubules inside cells, including neutrophils, affecting their mobility and reducing their recruitment to sites of inflammation.

 

Explanation of All Other Options:

 

A. Montelukast: Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used mainly for asthma and allergic rhinitis. While it can reduce inflammation, its primary action is not on neutrophil recruitment.

 

B. Sodium Cromolyn: Sodium cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer used to treat conditions like asthma and allergic rhinitis. It prevents the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators from mast cells but doesn't directly inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

D. Febuxostat: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used for the treatment of chronic gout. It reduces uric acid production but doesn't specifically inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Therefore, Colchicine is the drug that inhibits neutrophil recruitment, making option C the correct answer.

questions.text: A known alcoholic is brought to the emergency department by his wife. The person has not consumed alcohol for the past two days due to religious reasons. The person complained of nausea, vomiting and dizziness. On the second day, he developed seizures, that progressed to generalized tonic clonic seizures (GTCs). Which of the following would be the best medication to manage the seizures of the patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Diazepam

 

Explanation of each option:

 

OPTION C) Diazepam:

  • Diazepam is a benzodiazepine and is the preferred medication for managing alcohol withdrawal seizures. It has a rapid onset of action and helps to control seizures effectively. Additionally, benzodiazepines like diazepam can also help alleviate the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal syndrome, which often includes seizures.

OPTION A) Sodium valproate:

  • Sodium valproate is an antiepileptic medication commonly used to prevent and control seizures. However, in the case of acute alcohol withdrawal seizures, benzodiazepines like diazepam are preferred as the first-line treatment due to their rapid onset of action and effectiveness in managing alcohol withdrawal seizures.

OPTION B) Phenytoin:

  • Phenytoin is another antiepileptic medication used to control seizures. While it is effective for some types of seizures, it is not the first choice for managing alcohol withdrawal seizures. Benzodiazepines are preferred in this context.

OPTION D) Clonidine:

  • Clonidine is not typically used to manage seizures. It is primarily used to treat conditions such as high blood pressure and certain withdrawal symptoms. It is not the first-line treatment for alcohol withdrawal seizures.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE :

 

Long acting benzodiazepines such as chlordiazepoxide and diazepam or short acting such as lorazepam can be used to treat mild-moderate uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal.'

questions.text: Identify the marked cell from the given histological image of cerebellum
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Purkinje cells

 

The cells marked in the above histological image are Purkinje cells.

 

 

[*Purkinje layer in place of ganglionic layer in image]

 

Characteristics of Purkinje cells:

  • These are among the largest neurons in the brain, located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • They are flask-shaped cells arranged in a single layer with even spacing.
  • Each Purkinje cell has a dendrite that rises from its neck and enters the molecular layer, where it branches extensively to form a dendritic tree.
  • The axon of each cell descends, crosses the granular cell layer, and enters the white matter. These axons are the only efferent fibers of the cerebellar cortex.
  • The initial segment of the axon receives synaptic contacts from basket cell axons, which provide inhibitory feedback.
  • The main axon terminates in one of the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei, where it synapses with other neurons to modulate motor function.
  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use the neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) to regulate cerebellar output.

Let's discuss the mentioned other cell types in relation to the histology of the cerebellum:

 

Option B. Basket cells:

  • These are inhibitory interneurons found in the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • Their axons give rise to basket-like formations that surround the soma and initial axon segment of the Purkinje cells, hence the name.
  • They play a role in modulating the activity of Purkinje cells.

Option C. Golgi cells:

  • These are also inhibitory interneurons, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • Their dendrites extend into the molecular layer where they synapse with the parallel fibers of granule cells.
  • Golgi cells provide feedback inhibition to granule cells, modulating their output.

Option D. Granule cells:

  • These are the most numerous neurons in the brain, located in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • They are excitatory neurons that receive input from the cerebellar afferents through the mossy fibers.
  • Their axons ascend into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate and run parallel to the surface, forming the parallel fibers. These fibers synapse with the dendrites of the Purkinje cells.

questions.text: A 23y woman has been taking isotretinoin for acne. She now is recently married and is planning conception.  After how long of stopping isotretinoin should she conceive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 weeks

 

Isotretinoin:

  • Isotretinoin is contraindicated during pregnancy as one of the stronger teratogen
  • Retinoic acid embryopathy— that involve the CNS, face, heart, and thymus.
  • Specific anomalies may include ventriculomegaly, maldevelopment of the facial bones or cranium, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, conotruncal heart defects, and thymic aplasia or hypoplasia
  • Two reliable forms of birth control must be used at the same time (unless abstinence is the chosen method) for 1 month before, during, and for at least 1 month after concluding treatment with isotretinoin.
  • The most recent, and most stringent, system aimed to avoid exposure to isotretinoin is an Internet-based, performance-linked system called iPLEDGE
  • Isotretinoin and its active metabolites cross the human placenta. Isotretinoin is one of the strongest human teratogens known today.
  • The prevalence of birth defects after exposure during embryogenesis is as high as 30%.
  • Multiple organ systems are affected, including CNS, cardiovascular, and endocrine organs, and the damage can be severe.
  • Mental retardation without malformation has also been reported.

questions.text: Contraindications to epidural analgesia include the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Hypertension

 

Explanation:

 

OPTION D: Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is not typically a contraindication to epidural analgesia. In fact, epidural analgesia can be beneficial for patients with hypertension, as it can help control pain and reduce stress, potentially lowering blood pressure.

 

OPTION A. Raised Intracranial Pressure (ICP):

  • Contraindication: This is a contraindication to epidural analgesia. Epidural analgesia can potentially affect cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure, and using it in patients with raised ICP can be dangerous.

OPTION B. Coagulopathy:

  • Contraindication: Coagulopathy, a condition where the blood's ability to clot is impaired, is a contraindication to epidural analgesia. Inserting an epidural needle into the epidural space can cause bleeding, which is a risk in patients with coagulopathy.

OPTION C. Infection Over the Back:

  • Contraindication: Infection over the back, especially near the site where the epidural needle will be inserted, is a contraindication. Introducing a needle into an infected area can lead to the spread of infection.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

 

Epidural analgesia is a medical procedure commonly used for pain management, especially during labor and delivery or for postoperative pain control. While it is generally safe and effective, there are certain contraindications and precautions that healthcare providers must consider to ensure the patient's safety.

questions.text: A death certificate is given below. What is the underlying cause of death in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carcinoma breast

 

Explanation: Lowest line of part I or in this image I (c) is “Underlying cause of death” – It is the disease or condition that started the sequence of events that lead to death. In this image it is Carcinoma Breast.

 

Other Options

 

Option A) Type 2 diabetes mellitus: It is Part ll of death certificate which is for “Other significant conditions that contributed to the death”

 

Option B) Myocardial infarction: It is Part I(a), which is for “immediate cause of death”

 

Option D) Metastasis to bone: It is Part I(b), a line which is between the lowest and first lines which is for “antecedent cause(s)” of death,

 

Educational Objective

 

The medical part of the certificate consists of two parts-
 

Part I. Sequence of events leading to death -

  • First line of part I is the “immediate cause of death” – the condition / disease that directly led to death / that preceded death.
  • Lines in between the lowest and first lines are “antecedent cause(s)” of death
  • Lowest line of part I is “Underlying cause of death” – It is the disease or condition that started the sequence of events that lead to death.

The disease or circumstances of accident/violence, which started the chain, is the “Underlying Cause of Death” and the subsequent events in the chain are called as “Antecedent Cause” and “Immediate Cause of death”, in that order.

 

Part II. Other significant conditions that contributed to the death


All other diseases or conditions believed to have unfavorably influenced the course of the disease leading to death, but were not related to the disease or condition directly causing death.

 

If there is only one condition antecedent to the immediate cause, then line (c) should be kept blank.

 

Death certificate template used in India is given below:

 

 

https://www.ncdirindia.org/e-mor/MCCD_WEB.aspx#:~:text=(a)%20the%20disease%20or%20injury,as%20antecedent%20and%20immediate%20cause.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?

  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche - absent
  • FSH, LH - high
  • Karyotype - 46 XX
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Gonadal dysgenesis

  • The probable diagnosis, in this case, is pure gonadal dysgenesis.
  • Whenever secondary sexual characters are ABSENT, think of ovarian or hypothalamic/pituitary causes.
  • If FSH/ LH is low – think of hypothalamic or pituitary causes (Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism)
  • If FSH/ LH is high, think of ovarian cause (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism)
    • 46 XX – gonadal dysgenesis
    • 46 XY – Swyer syndrome

Other Options:

  • Option A: Testicular Feminization Syndrome/ Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome:
    • 46XY
    • Uterus and ovaries absent
    • Secondary sexual development (especially breast development +) due to peripheral production of estrogens.
       
  • Option C: Kallman Syndrome
    • This is a cause of Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism leading to primary amenorrhoea
    • Associated with anosmia
    • Absent secondary sexual characters
    • FSH and LH: Low
       
  • Option D
    • 45XO
    • Streak ovaries leading to low estrogen and absent secondary sexual characters
    • FSH and LH are high
    • Very important feature: Short stature

 

Ref: Page no 454, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with general weakness, light-headedness, and a sensation of pins and needles in his feet. He has a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Laboratory findings show macrocytic anemia and low serum vitamin B12 levels. A gastric biopsy indicates atrophic gastritis and loss of parietal cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pernicious Anemia

 

Explanation:

  1. Pernicious Anemia (Answer B): This condition is characterized by the autoimmune destruction of gastric parietal cells, which are responsible for secreting intrinsic factor, a protein essential for the absorption of vitamin B12. The patient’s symptoms of weakness, light-headedness, and neuropathy (pins and needles) are classic for vitamin B12 deficiency. Macrocytic anemia and low serum B12 levels further support this diagnosis. The presence of atrophic gastritis and loss of parietal cells on gastric biopsy aligns with this diagnosis. Additionally, the patient’s history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, another autoimmune condition, increases the likelihood of him having pernicious anemia, as autoimmune diseases often cluster together.
  2. Iron Deficiency Anemia (Answer A): While this can cause general weakness, it typically presents with microcytic anemia (small red blood cells), not macrocytic anemia (large red blood cells), which is observed in this patient.
  3. Vitamin B6 Deficiency (Answer C): Deficiency of Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) can cause neuropathy but is less likely to cause macrocytic anemia. It's more commonly associated with sideroblastic anemia.
  4. Chronic Gastritis due to Helicobacter pylori (Answer D): While H. pylori infection can cause chronic gastritis, it does not typically result in macrocytic anemia or vitamin B12 deficiency unless it has progressed to atrophic gastritis involving the entire stomach, which is less common.

Given these considerations, Pernicious Anemia is the most appropriate diagnosis for this patient’s presentation and findings.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with fever, cough, and shortness of breath. Her chest X-ray shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Which of the following chemical mediators is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of her acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-α)

 

TNF-α is a cytokine that is released by activated macrophages and is involved in the pathogenesis of acute lung injury. In patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), TNF-α promotes the recruitment of neutrophils and other inflammatory cells to the lungs, leading to the release of proteases and other enzymes that contribute to tissue damage and impaired gas exchange.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the active form of calcium?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ionised calcium

 

Explanation of each option:

 

Option A .Ionized calcium: This is the correct answer. Ionized calcium represents the physiologically active form of calcium in the bloodstream. It is the portion of calcium that is not bound to proteins or other molecules and is readily available for various biological functions.

 

Option B. Albumin bound calcium: Albumin-bound calcium refers to calcium ions that are bound to the protein albumin in the blood. While this form is considered a reservoir of calcium, it is not as readily available for cellular processes as ionized calcium.

 

Option C. Phosphate-bound calcium: Calcium can bind to phosphate in the blood, but this is not the primary active form of calcium. In fact, excessive calcium-phosphate binding can lead to the formation of calcium phosphate crystals, which can be harmful.

 

Option D. Protein-bound calcium: This term is similar to albumin-bound calcium. Calcium can also bind to other proteins in the blood, but it is primarily the ionized calcium that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes.

OPTION D. Blowout Fracture:

Ans. A. Left optic nerve and chiasma

Junctional scotoma and the junctional scotoma of Traquair are visual field defects that arise from damage to the junction of the optic nerve and the optic chiasm. Sellar masses including pituitary tumors are the most common cause of these visual field defects. Ophthalmologic findings include ipsilateral central scotoma and typically a contralateral superior temporal visual field defect (junctional scotoma, JS)

 

The patient has left centrocecal scotoma. So the left optic nerve is affected. The patient also has an upper temporal field defect on the right side probably due to an early chiasma lesion.

questions.text: A young boy presents to the emergency department with sudden shortness of breath. He also complains of abdominal pain and few episodes of vomiting. In the hospital, he slowly developed a rash on his chest, arms, and legs. His breathing became faster with audible wheezing. On physical examination, he had hypotension and tachycardia. A rash is on his right arm, as shown in the image. After being administered appropriate treatment, the boy improves significantly, and he is able to breathe comfortably. Which of the following is the best marker that could be measured in the serum of this boy to help establish a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tryptase

 

Anaphylaxis is a systemic hypersensitivity reaction usually involving two or more organs including skin/mucus membranes, airways, cardiovascular, and/or gastrointestinal systems.The current gold standard laboratory test involves measurement of serum total tryptase during an acute phase followed by a baseline measurement (≥24 h). Whilst a rise in serum total mast cell tryptase (MCT) is diagnostic, this is not seen in all cases of anaphylaxis.

questions.text:
Which are features of false labor?

  1. Steady intensity of pain
  2. Cervical dilation
  3. Discomfort is in the back and abdomen
  4. Intervals remain long
  5. Discomfort usually is relieved by sedation
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A, D, E

 

Characteristic of True & False Labor

 

True Labor

  •  Contractions occur at regular intervals.
  •  Intervals gradually shorten.
  •  Intensity gradually increases.
  •  Discomfort is in the back and abdomen.
  •  Cervix dilates.
  •  Discomfort is not stopped by sedation.

False Labor

  •  Contractions occur at irregular intervals.
  •  Intervals remain long.
  •  Intensity remains unchanged.
  •  Discomfort is chiefly in the lower abdomen.
  •  Cervix does not dilate.
  •  Discomfort usually is relieved by sedation.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents for a routine check-up. He has no complaints of chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations. His blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, heart rate is 72 bpm, and respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute. On physical examination, his heart sounds are normal with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. An ECG is performed as part of his evaluation.

 

ECG Findings:

 

  • Sinus rhythm
  • QRS duration >120 ms
  • RSR' pattern in V1 and V2
  • Wide, slurred S wave in leads I, V5, and V6

Based on the ECG findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right Bundle Branch Block

 

Explanation:

  1. Right Bundle Branch Block (Answer B): The ECG findings are characteristic of RBBB. These include a QRS duration greater than 120 milliseconds, indicating a delay in ventricular depolarization. The RSR' pattern in leads V1 and V2, often described as a ‘rabbit ear’ sign, is a hallmark of RBBB. It represents delayed depolarization of the right ventricle. Additionally, the wide, slurred S wave in leads I, V5, and V6 are also typical findings in RBBB, as these leads view the left ventricle and show the delayed right ventricular activation as a late S wave.
  2. Left Bundle Branch Block (Answer A): In contrast, a left bundle branch block (LBBB) would typically show a broad QRS complex with a dominant S wave in V1 and a dominant R wave in V6, which is not present here.
  3. Anterior Myocardial Infarction (Answer C): While an anterior MI can cause QRS changes, it typically presents with ST elevations or Q waves in the anterior leads (V1-V4), not the typical pattern of RBBB.
  4. Atrial Fibrillation (Answer D): Atrial fibrillation would present with an irregularly irregular rhythm and absence of distinct P waves, neither of which are described in this ECG.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a noticeable bulge in his lower abdomen that becomes more pronounced when he's in a standing position. Upon examination, hernia is identified located medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

 

The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia, for which Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for its management.

 

Hernia lateral to inferior epigastric artery is an indirect inguinal hernia, which is managed by herniotomy + Hernioplasty.

 

Other surgical methods used for the repair of hernia are:

  • Bassini repair: a surgical technique used to repair inguinal hernias in adults, without the use of a mesh, by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches or conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament. It is mainly used in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis and has a high recurrence rate.
  • Shouldice repair: a multilayered repair technique for inguinal hernias, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures and double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It has a very low recurrence rate and is preferred in young and active patients.

questions.text: A 25 y primigravida with a known history of epilepsy on sodium valproate presents to the antenatal OPD at 6 weeks. All are advised except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sodium valproate is safe and can be continued safely

 

Pregnancy and epilepsy

  • Generally low risk to the fetus.
  • There is an increased risk of major congenital malformations due to AEDs (Table 1). However certain AEDS like lamotrigine, levetiracetam and carbamazepine are commonly used and considered the safest agents. Poly-therapy increases the risk of malformations.
  • Sodium valproate infers the highest risk of congenital malformations (especially Neural tube defects).
  • Increased risk of Fetal growth restriction in women on AEDs.
  • There is an increased risk of developing childhood epilepsy in the fetus.
  • Folic acid (5mg) should be taken pre conceptionally and throughout pregnancy to reduce the risk of congenital malformations and long-term cognitive effects
  • Aim for monotherapy with the longest effective AED dose if possible. If taking sodium valproate, this needs to be changed to an alternative AED

 

Ref:  William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe central chest pain that radiates to the back. He also complains of unequal pulses in both arms and denies about any trauma. On examination, the patient's pulse 180/100 mmHg. An X-ray of the chest is performed and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aortic dissection

 

The presence of unequal pulses in both arms, as observed in this patient, is a key clinical finding that suggests aortic dissection. Additionally, the elevated blood pressure (180/100 mmHg) is consistent with the increased stress on the aortic wall.

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION A:  SVC syndrome will present with flushing and congestion of face, in addition to dilated veins on examination.

 

OPTION B:  Blunt chest injury might cause chest pain but is unlikely to lead to unequal pulses unless there is a specific vascular injury, which is not described in the scenario.

 

OPTION C:  Cardiac tamponade can also cause chest pain and hemodynamic instability, but unequal pulses are not a characteristic feature of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Dr. Verma, a postgraduate student in the ObGy department at KGMU Mumbai, has a deep-rooted interest in maternal health and its impact on neonatal outcomes. While scrutinizing available literature for her PG research topic, she becomes intrigued by the correlation between maternal smoking and neonatal health. She hypothesizes that smoking during pregnancy might be a significant contributing factor to neonates being born with a low birth weight. To validate her hypothesis, She begins her study and starts gathering comprehensive data on the smoking habits of expectant mothers during their scheduled antenatal visits. Subsequently, as each baby is delivered, Dr. Verma meticulously notes down their birth weights. Given that the exposure, in this case, the smoking behavior, was recorded in anticipation of the future outcome, the birth weight. Which type of epidemiological research design is Dr. Verma utilizing?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prospective Cohort

 

Explanation - 

 

This design involves selecting participants based on their exposure status and then tracking them over time to observe the outcome. In Dr. Verma's study, she identified pregnant women based on their smoking habits (exposure) and then monitored the birth weights of their newborns (outcome) after delivery, and thus, the study of choice will be Cohort study.

 

Cohort Study

  • Is a type of analytical (observational) study used for ‘hypothesis testing’
  • Is also known as - 
    • Prospective study
    • Forward looking study
    • Cause to effect study
    • Exposure to outcome study
    • Risk factor to disease study
    • Incidence study
    • Follow up study

  • Homocystinuria
  • Argininemia
  • Lesch-nyhan disease
  • Maple syrup urine disease
  • Tyrosinemia
  • Tuberous sclerosis
  • Neurofibromatosis

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition

questions.text: An elderly woman with a recent history of myocardial infarction is seeking a medication to help treat her occasional heartburn. She is currently taking several medications, including aspirin, clopidogrel, simvastatin, metoprolol, and lisinopril. Which of the following choices should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Omeprazole

  • Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that can inhibit the enzyme CYP2C19, which is involved in the metabolism of clopidogrel. Inhibition of CYP2C19 prevents the activation and thus can reduce the effectiveness of clopidogrel, an anti-platelet drug.
  • Calcium citrate, famotidine, and ranitidine are all considered safe options for treating heartburn in patients with a history of myocardial infarction and taking multiple medications.

choices.text: Le forte II

questions.text: Craniofacial dysjunction is seen in
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Le Forte III

 

Le Fort III (craniofacial dysfunction). There is complete separation of facial bones from the cranial bones. The fracture line passes through root of nose, ethmofrontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of orbit, frontozygomatic and temporozygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates. Source Dhingra 6th edition 185

questions.text: A 31-year-old man is referred to an endocrinologist for evaluation of recurrent kidney stones and peptic ulcer disease that has been resistant to conventional treatments. He reports a history of severe heartburn and abdominal pain. His family history is significant for his father having had surgery for a pituitary tumor and a cousin diagnosed with thyroid cancer. On examination, he has mild proximal muscle weakness and a palpable neck mass. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum calcium, high parathyroid hormone (PTH), and increased gastrin levels. A thyroid ultrasound shows a nodule in the left thyroid lobe. Based on the clinical presentation, family history, and laboratory findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1 (MEN1)

 

Explanation:

  1. Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1 (MEN1): MEN1 is a hereditary condition characterized by tumors in multiple endocrine glands. The patient’s symptoms and lab findings are highly indicative of MEN1:
    • Recurrent kidney stones and peptic ulcer disease: These suggest primary hyperparathyroidism (evidenced by elevated serum calcium and high PTH) and a gastrin-secreting tumor (gastrinoma), respectively. Both are common in MEN1.
    • Family history of pituitary and thyroid tumors: MEN1 is associated with parathyroid tumors, pituitary tumors, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. The family history of similar issues strongly suggests a hereditary pattern consistent with MEN1.
    • Thyroid nodule: While not as classic for MEN1 as parathyroid or pituitary tumors, thyroid abnormalities can be associated with this condition.
       
  2. Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2 (MEN2) (Answer B): MEN2 more commonly involves medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid hyperplasia. The prominent features of gastrinoma and pituitary tumor in the patient's history are more characteristic of MEN1.
  3. Familial Hypocalciuric Hypercalcemia (Answer C): This condition usually presents with mild hypercalcemia and is not associated with multiple endocrine tumors or the range of symptoms seen in this patient.
  4. Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (Answer D): While the patient’s symptoms and elevated gastrin levels suggest Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome, this diagnosis alone does not account for the hyperparathyroidism, the thyroid nodule, and the family history of pituitary tumor. Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome can be a part of MEN1 but does not encompass the full spectrum of this patient’s clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 15 yrs old boy presented with painful swelling over right shoulder . X ray of the shoulder showed an Osteolytic area with stippled calcification over proximal humerus epiphysis . Further the orthopedic surgeon advised for biopsy of osteolytic area on the x ray. Biopsy of lesion revealed an immature fibrous matrix with scattered giant cells. X Rays taken revealed as follows. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Chondroblastoma

 

Explanation for each option:

 

OPTION C. Chondroblastoma:

  • Chondroblastoma is a benign bone tumor that typically affects the epiphysis (ends) of long bones and is more common in adolescents.
  • Radiographically, chondroblastomas often present as an osteolytic (bone-destructive) lesion with stippled (speckled) calcification, which matches the X-ray findings.
  • Microscopically, chondroblastomas are characterized by an immature fibrous matrix with scattered giant cells, consistent with the biopsy findings.

OPTION A. Chondromyxoid Fibroma:

  • Chondromyxoid fibroma is a rare benign bone tumor.
  • It typically occurs in the metaphysis of long bones, not in the proximal humerus epiphysis.
  • Radiographically, it presents as a well-defined, lytic (bone-destructive) lesion with chondroid matrix and myxoid components, which is different from the stippled calcification seen in the X-ray provided.
  • Histologically, chondromyxoid fibroma is characterized by chondroid and myxoid areas, but it does not typically show an immature fibrous matrix with scattered giant cells.

OPTION B. Enchondroma:

  • Enchondroma is another benign tumor that arises in the medullary cavity of long bones.
  • It typically does not present with stippled calcification, as seen in the X-ray provided.
  • Histologically, enchondromas consist of mature hyaline cartilage, which differs from the immature fibrous matrix and scattered giant cells described in the biopsy findings.

OPTION D. Giant Cell Tumor:

  • Giant cell tumor (GCT) of bone is typically found in the epiphysis, but it doesn't usually present with stippled calcifications.
  • Histologically, GCT is characterized by numerous multinucleated giant cells and stromal cells but lacks the immature fibrous matrix seen in the biopsy.

questions.text: Defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Type 1 Tyrosinemia

 

Explanation:

 

Hepatorenal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type I) aka Tyrosinosis –

  • Autosomal recessive, most common type of tyrosinemia.
  • Due to a deficiency of enzyme fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase.
  • Symptoms manifest by the first 6 months of life and death occurs rapidly. Cabbage like odor and hypoglycemia and eventual liver failure are seen. There may be mild mental retardation.
  • Urine contains tyrosine, para-hydroxyphenyl pyruvic acid (p-HPPA) and hydroxyphenyl lactic acid; and serum shows tyrosine.
  • Tyrosine and phenylalanine restricted diet is advised.

Oculocutaneous Tyrosinemia/ Richner-Hanhart Syndrome (Tyrosinemia Type II) is due to deficiency of tyrosine amino transferase (tyrosine transaminase). Mental retardation, keratosis of palmar surface, painful corneal lesions and photophobia are seen. There is increased excretion of tyrosine and tyramine in urine. A diet low in protein is advised.

 

Neonatal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type III) is due to the absence of the enzyme para-hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase. This deficiency may cause transient hypertyrosinemia in the new born; this will respond to administration of ascorbic acid and dietary protein restriction.

questions.text: A 34-year-old clinical researcher is preparing to launch a new trial to test the efficacy of a novel antihypertensive drug compared to a standard treatment. While reviewing the protocol, he seeks to ensure the study design minimizes biases that could impact the validity of the trial results. He specifically aims to reduce any potential differences between the treatment and control groups that could arise due to non-random assignment of participants, as these could confound the study outcomes. Among the following methods, which would be the most effective in ensuring that participants in both groups are comparable at baseline, thereby minimizing selection bias?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Randomization

 

Explanation - 

 

Randomisation in Randomized Controlled trial (RCT) is a statistical procedure by which participants are allocated into either of two groups  - Experimental Group (in which intervention is given) and Reference Group (in which intervention is not given)

 

Randomization is done to remove selection bias. It ensures comparability of both the groups by removal of both known and unknown confounding factors.

 

Randomization is Superior to BOTH Matching and Blinding

 

 

Other Options - 

  • Option A Matching: Involves pairing individuals who have similar characteristics before allocating them to treatment groups. It's primarily used in observational studies to control confounding, but it does not eliminate the risk of selection bias inherent in non-random assignment.
  • Option B Blinding: This technique ensures that the participants, caregivers, or those evaluating the outcomes do not know which treatment the participant received, thereby preventing measurement and observer bias. 
  • Option D Stratification: Involves dividing participants into subgroups based on one or more characteristics, and then randomizing within these strata. It ensures balance between treatment groups in terms of the stratified variable, but by itself, it does not eliminate selection bias.

choices.text: Police not under rank of sub inspector

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Patient

 

Explanation: In a civil negligence case against a doctor, the burden of proof or onus of proof typically rests with the patient, who is the person bringing the lawsuit.

 

Other options

 

Option B) Police not under rank of sub inspector: The police investigate criminal negligence, which is different from civil negligence, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C) Magistrate: The magistrate in a civil negligence case against a doctor does not bear the burden of proof. It’s the responsibility of the patient or plaintiff to prove the doctor’s negligence, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option D) Doctor: In a civil negligence case against a doctor, the burden of proof does not automatically fall on the doctor. Instead, it’s the responsibility of the patient or plaintiff who brings the case to prove that the doctor’s actions were negligent. The doctor is considered innocent until proven otherwise in a civil lawsuit, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective

 

“Onus of proof” implies the responsibility to prove or disprove a crime.

 

As a general rule, the onus to proof lies with the victim (or his lawyer), and not with the accused, in both civil and criminal cases. The accused is assumed to be innocent. It is the responsibility of victim (or his lawyer) to prove that accused has done a crime.

 

In criminal case, the burden of proof is always on the state (i.e., the public prosecutor, the government lawyer for victim). The state must prove that the accused is guilty.

 

In civil case, the burden of proof lies on the plaintiff. The plaintiff is a person who brings a case against another in a civil court. The person against whom the case is filed is called defendant. For e.g. in a medical negligence case, the patient is the plaintiff and the doctor is the defendant. Ordinarily the patient (and his lawyer) has to prove that the Doctor is negligent.  

 

Exceptions where onus of proof lies with accused:

  • RES IPSA LOQUITOR (the thing or action speaks of itself)
  • Insanity: If the defendant wishes to claim that he/she is insane, and therefore not guilty, the defendant bears the burden of proving his/her insanity.
  • 114-A CrPc: In a case of rape, where sexual intercourse by the accused is proved and the question is whether it was without the consent of the woman alleged to have been raped, the court shall presume that she did not consent. The accused will have to prove that it was with consent.
  • Contributory Negligence: If a doctor wants to take the defense of contributory negligence, then he will have to prove that the patient was also negligent along with him.

questions.text: A 29-year-old multigravida presents at 15 weeks gestation to establish prenatal care. The patient’s first child had a neural tube defect. The patient did not know that she was pregnant till this week so she asks you about starting folic acid as she was earlier counseled at the time of her 1st pregnancy to take a higher dose of folic acid. Which of the following statements will you mention during couneling?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. The neural tube closes by 6 weeks so folic acid needs to be taken before 6 weeks

 

Explanation

  • Pre-conceptional Folic Acid should be taken in all women planning to conceive and if not started pre-conceptionally, should be started before 6 weeks of pregnancy (Before the neural tube closes)
    • 0.04 mg/ day to low risk
    • 4 mg/ day to high risk for neural tube defects - NTD. Women at high risk for NTD are
      • H/o previous baby with NTD
      • Pre-gestational Diabetes Mellitus               
      • Folic acid deficiency
      • Obesity

      • Hemoglobinopathy

questions.text:
Which of the following is correctly matched?

  1. Dopamine – mesangial relaxation
  2. Endothelin – mesangial contraction
  3. Vasopressin – mesangial contraction
  4. Histamine – mesangial relaxation
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1,2,3

  • Mesangial cells are specialized contractile cells found around the glomerulus, which are involved in the structural support and regulation of glomerular filtration and blood flow and also involved in the responses to injury and in remodeling
  • Histamine will cause contraction of the mesangial cells (not relaxation)
  • Dopamine will cause relaxation of the mesangial cells
  • Vasopressin and endothelin will cause contraction of the mesangial cells

 

(Refer :  Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, pg. no: 678)

choices.text: It is an antibody produced entirely from mice containing no human component.
It is a monoclonal antibody produced by injecting the HER2 antigen.
It is a polyclonal antibody.
It is a monoclonal antibody containing only human components.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents with breast carcinoma, and she was prescribed Herceptin (trastuzumab). Which of the following statements regarding this drug is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is a monoclonal antibody produced by injecting the HER2 antigen.

  • Herceptin (trastuzumab) is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets the human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) protein, which is overexpressed in approximately 25% of breast cancers. It is produced by injecting the HER2 antigen into mice and then harvesting the resulting monoclonal antibodies.
  • Unlike some other monoclonal antibodies, It contains both mouse and human components, making it a chimeric antibody. The mouse-derived portion of the antibody binds to the HER2 antigen, while the human portion helps to reduce the risk of an immune reaction to the drug.

questions.text: An 84-year-old woman with a history of ischaemic heart disease is reviewed in the dermatology clinic. Her current medication includes aspirin, simvastatin, bisoprolol, ramipril and isosorbide mononitrate. She has developed tense blistering lesions on her legs as shown in the image below. Each lesion is around 1 to 3 cm in diameter and she reports that they are slightly pruritic. Examination of her mouth and vulva is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bullous pemphigoid

 

Explanation of each option:

 

OPTION D. Bullous pemphigoid

  • It is an autoimmune blistering disorder with antibodies against Hemidesmosomal proteins BP180 and BP230
  • that primarily affects older individuals and presents with tense blisters on the skin, often on the legs and arms.
  • Mucous membrane involvement is less common than in pemphigus.
  • Given the patient's age, clinical presentation, and medication history, bullous pemphigoid is the most likely diagnosis.
  • A skin biopsy and immunofluorescence testing can confirm the diagnosis.
  • Histopathology of Bullous Pemphigoid showing Subepidermal split:

  • Immunofluorescence shows IgG and C3 at the dermoepidermal junction in a Linear pattern.

OPTION A. Pemphigus

  • It is a group of autoimmune blistering disorders characterized by the formation of fragile blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes.

  • It typically presents with flaccid blisters and is often associated with involvement of the mouth and mucous membranes, which are not mentioned in the patient's presentation.

OPTION B. Drug reaction to aspirin

 

This can cause various skin reactions, including urticaria or fixed drug eruptions, but it is less likely to cause tense blistering lesions like those described in the case.

 

OPTION C. Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

  • This is a genetic disorder characterized by blistering of the skin and mucous membranes in response to minor trauma or friction.
  • It usually presents in childhood and is not typically associated with the development of tense blisters in an elderly patient without a previous history of the condition.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

 

In an elderly patient with tense blistering lesions on the legs and a history of ischaemic heart disease, the most likely diagnosis is bullous pemphigoid

 

 

Reference:  Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 page no 50.10

Online resources:

https://dermnetnz.org/topics/bullous-pemphigoid

questions.text: A 4-year-old male presents with coarse facial features, enlarged liver and spleen, and a progressive decline in cognitive abilities. Urine analysis reveals the presence of glycosaminoglycans. Corneal clouding was absent. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for the symptoms observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Iduronate Sulfatase

 

Explanation:

 

This patient likely has Hunter syndrome, an X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disorder. The deficiency of Iduronate Sulfatase leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) in tissues, resulting in symptoms such as coarse facial features, enlarged liver and spleen, and cognitive decline. Notably, corneal clouding is absent in Hunter syndrome, which helps distinguish it from Hurler syndrome, another mucopolysaccharidosis where corneal clouding is a characteristic feature.

questions.text: Kumar is a 35-year-old high school teacher who has been feeling consistently sad and fatigued for the past six months. He struggles to get out of bed and often contemplates calling in sick. Kumar has lost interest in hobbies he once enjoyed, like playing the guitar and hiking. He frequently finds himself feeling guilty about being unable to engage with his students as energetically as he used to. Kumar 's appetite has decreased, leading to significant weight loss. He also mentions difficulty sleeping and feels pessimistic about the future. Kumar 's sister, who had experienced a similar episode in the past, recommended he see a psychiatrist. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for Kumar?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Major Depressive Disorder (MDD)

 

Explanation of each option:

 

OPTION C: Major Depressive Disorder (MDD):

  • Major Depressive Disorder is characterized by persistent and severe depressive symptoms, such as sadness, fatigue, loss of interest in activities, changes in appetite and weight, sleep disturbances, feelings of guilt or worthlessness, and pessimism about the future. David's symptoms align closely with those of MDD, including a duration of at least six months.

OPTION A: Bipolar I Disorder:

  • Bipolar I Disorder is characterized by mood swings that include manic episodes (periods of elevated mood and energy) and depressive episodes (periods of low mood and energy). While David is experiencing depressive symptoms, there is no mention of manic or hypomanic episodes in the scenario, making this diagnosis less likely.

OPTION B: Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD):

  • Seasonal Affective Disorder is a type of depression that occurs seasonally, typically during the fall and winter months when there is less natural sunlight. David's symptoms have persisted for the past six months, which is not consistent with the seasonal pattern seen in SAD. Additionally, SAD symptoms often improve during the spring and summer, while David's symptoms have not shown improvement.

OPTION D: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD):

 

Generalized Anxiety Disorder is primarily characterized by excessive worry and anxiety, rather than the profound sadness and loss of interest seen in David's case. While anxiety can coexist with depression, the primary presentation in this scenario appears to be depressive symptoms.


EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE :

 

Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), often simply referred to as depression, is a mental health disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness and a lack of interest or pleasure in previously enjoyable activities. It affects how one feels, thinks, and behaves and can lead to various emotional and physical problems.

 

Symptoms: MDD can have a broad range of symptoms, but the following are the most common:

  1. Depressed mood: Persistent feelings of sadness, emptiness, or hopelessness.
  2. Loss of interest or pleasure: Decreased interest in most or all activities, especially those that were once enjoyable.
  3. Changes in appetite or weight: Significant weight loss or weight gain, or a decrease or increase in appetite.
  4. Sleep disturbances: Insomnia or sleeping too much.
  5. Physical agitation or slowing: Restlessness or reduced physical activity noticeable by others.
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy: Feeling tired nearly every day.
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt: Harsh self-assessment or guilt over perceived past failures.
  8. Reduced ability to think, concentrate, or make decisions: May manifest as indecisiveness or forgetfulness.
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death or suicide: This can be without a specific plan or with intent or a plan to commit suicide.

questions.text: A person with history of 30 years working in sugarcane industry, develops breathlessness and cough. X-rays show mottling in lungs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bagasossis

 

Explanation - 

 

Bagassosis is an airborne disease caused by inhalation of the fibrous cane-sugar residue, bagasse.

 

H/O working in sugarcane industry supports the diagnosis.

 

Bagasse dust blocks bronchioles thus leading to bronchitis and bronchopneumonia. It has been shown to be due to Thermoactinomyces sacchari. 

 

Prevention and Bagasse control measures are Keeping the moisture content > 20% and Spraying bagasse with 2% propionic acid (fungicide). 

 

Other Options - 

 

 Asbestosis

  • Asbestosis is a pneumoconiosis that occurs due to: Exposure to asbestos dust.  Asbestosis does not usually appear until after 5-10 years of exposure
  • Sputum shows ‘asbestos bodies’, which are asbestos fibres coated with fibrin. Lung show “Ground glass appearance” on chest X-ray. 
  • Asbestos may lead to pulmonary fibrosis, carcinoma of bronchus, mesothelioma of peritoneum/pleura and cancer of GIT.
  • Asbestos type most dangerous is ‘amphibole’.

Byssinosis: Caused by inhalation of cotton dust, leading to chest tightness and breathlessness. Monday fever/ Monday sickness is associated with Byssinosis.

questions.text: Match the following signs seen in acute appendicitis with their respective features?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Rovsing’s sign: On pressing the LIF, pain is elicited at the RIF

 

Psoas sign: Occasionally, an inflamed appendix lies on the psoas muscle, and the patient, often a young adult, will lie with the right hip flexed for pain relief (the psoas sign).

 

Obturator sign: Spasm of the obturator internus is sometimes demonstrable when the hip is flexed and internally rotated. If an inflamed appendix is in contact with the obturator internus, this manoeuvre will cause pain in the hypogastrium (the obturator test; Zachary Cope).

 

Blumberg sign: Gentle superficial palpation of the abdomen, beginning in the left iliac fossa and moving anticlockwise to the right iliac fossa, will detect muscle guarding over the point of maximum tenderness, classically McBurney’s point. Asking the patient to cough or gentle percussion over the site of maximum tenderness will elicit rebound tenderness.

 

 

Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Ed., 1339 pg

questions.text: Blood supply to deep cerebellar nuclei is from?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Superior cerebellar artery

 

Superior cerebellar artery a branch of basilar artery supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum and the deep cerebellar nuclei

 

 

Incorrect answers

  • C-Anteroinferior cerebellar artery arises from basilar artery and in 85% gives rise to labyrinthine artery which supplies the structures of inner ear (cochlea and vestibular apparatus)
  • D-Posterior cerebral artery is the terminal branch of basilar artery

 

 

Ref. Vishram singh Textbook of clinical neuroanatomy, 2nd edition pg 174

questions.text: A Mother brings her 4-year-old child Ramya with features of intellectual disability and refractory seizures. On evaluation, she had a normal physical appearance. A spine X ray reveals the presence of Hemi vertebrae and the MRI image of the child is given below. What is the likely diagnosis based on the clinical features and the radiological findings?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Aicardi syndrome

  • Aicardi syndrome represents a complex disorder that affects many systems and is typically associated with agenesis of the corpus callosum, distinctive chorio-retinal lacunae, and infantile spasms.
  • Seizures become evident during the 1st few months and are typically resistant to anticonvulsants.
  • An EEG shows independent activity recorded from both hemispheres as a result of the absent corpus callosum and shows often hemihypsarrhythmia.
  • MRI will show the agenesis of Corpus callosum.
  • All patients have severe intellectual disability and can have abnormal vertebrae that may be fused or only partially developed (hemi vertebra).
  • Abnormalities of the retina, including circumscribed pits or lacunae and coloboma of the optic disc, are the most characteristic findings of Aicardi syndrome.

Option A, B and C: doesn’t correlate with the clinical features and the radiological features of Aicardi syndrome.

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No: 557

questions.text:
Which of the following are true about gastric acid secretion?

  1. Parietal cell derived
  2.  Primary active transport
  3. Diffusion of H+ ions
  4. Potassium channels involved
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1,2,4

  • The gastric acid (hydrochloric acid) will be secreted from the parietal cells (H+ and Cl-)
  • The proton pumps (or hydrogen potassium ATPase, H-K-ATPase) are involved in the secretion of hydrogen ions
  • These hydrogen ions are pumped out against the concentration gradient through active transport (not passive transport)
  • The potassium channels in the apical membrane will also be involved (for the exchange of potassium ions for hydrogen ions)

 

(Refer: Ganong’ s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 458)

questions.text: A 40-year-old epidemiologist is tasked with visually representing the current outbreak of diarrhea in a district of Kerala, India. She wants to showcase the trends and fluctuations of the cases over a period of time to the local health authorities. Which type of graphical representation would be the most appropriate for her to use in order to display these temporal trends effectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Line Chart

 

Explanation -  

 

Line chart or graph is a frequency polygon presenting variations by time.

 

 

 

It shows the trend of an event over a period of time. Like diarrhea cases in an epidemic area over a period of given time.

 

Bar diagram: it is for visual comparison of magnitude of different frequencies in a data.

 

 

Pie diagram: it is for presentation of discrete data of qualitative characteristics.

 

 

Spot map: is prepared to show geographical distribution of frequencies of characteristic.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. The child's mother reports that the child has been losing weight and has a poor appetite for the past few months. The child has also been suffering from recurrent infections. On examination, the child's weight for height is decreased and the child's height for age is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Wasting

 

As the child's weight for height is below the 70% of the expected value, indicating wasting.

 

The child's weight for height is decreased indicating that the child is suffering from wasting, a form of malnutrition characterized by rapid weight loss and muscle wasting. However, the child's height for age is normal, indicating the absence of chronic malnutrition or stunting. Recurrent infections and poor appetite can contribute to the development of wasting. Therefore, the correct answer is C. Wasting.

 

Option A. Chronic malnutrition - Chronic malnutrition is not present in this case because for chronic malnutrition the parameter affected is height for age

 

Option B. Stunting - Stunting is not present in this case, as the child's height for age is normal.

 

Option D. Obesity - This option is incorrect because the child's weight for height is decreased indicating malnutrition, rather than obesity.

 

 

Ref- Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of episodic gross hematuria, often occurring within a day or two after a respiratory tract infection. He reports no significant pain during urination, but the change in urine color concerns him. His medical history is otherwise unremarkable. His blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Laboratory tests reveal normal renal function, but urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria with red blood cell casts. There is no evidence of proteinuria.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. IgA Nephropathy (Berger’s Disease)

 

Explanation:

  • IgA Nephropathy (Berger’s Disease) (Answer B): This patient's presentation of episodic gross hematuria that typically occurs following an upper respiratory tract infection is a classic feature of IgA Nephropathy. IgA Nephropathy is the most common form of primary glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by the deposition of IgA antibodies in the glomerular mesangium. The finding of microscopic hematuria with red blood cell casts in the urinalysis further supports this diagnosis. The absence of significant proteinuria and the episodic nature of the symptoms, often following infections, are typical for IgA Nephropathy.
  • Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (Answer A): While this condition also presents with hematuria, it typically follows a streptococcal infection (like a sore throat or impetigo) and may include symptoms such as edema and hypertension. The urinalysis might show similar findings, but the history of episodic hematuria following respiratory infections is more indicative of IgA Nephropathy.
  • Membranous Nephropathy (Answer C): Membranous Nephropathy typically presents with proteinuria, often in the nephrotic range, and is less commonly associated with hematuria. The clinical history provided does not align well with this diagnosis.
  • Minimal Change Disease (Answer D): This condition primarily presents with nephrotic syndrome, characterized by significant proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema. It is less likely to present with isolated hematuria and episodic symptoms post-infection, as seen in this patient.
