questions.text: Organ least affected in Graft - Versus host Disease is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lung

 

Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) occurs due to the presence of immunocompetent T lymphocytes in the graft attacking the immunodeficient recipient tissue due to histocompatibility differences within 100 days, causing tissue damage.

 

Organ most affected by GVHD - Skin

 

Organ least affected by GVHD - Lung

 

Any organ can be affected in GVH reaction. The most important is the involvement of immune system, skin, liver and intestines.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presented with symptoms suggestive of pneumonia with allergic manifestations. His serum IgE levels were very high and Eosinophil count was more than normal. Peripheral blood smear and stool examination showed no abnormal reports. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

 

In this scenario, raised eosinophils are suggestive of parasitic infection and raised IgE means an allergic manifestation.

 

Occult filariasis means a hypersensitivity reaction that occurs to filarial antigens; In this condition, the microfilariae cannot be seen in peripheral blood; the most common manifestation is TPE (Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia).

 

Other options:

 

Option B – Atopic dermatitis is an immune mediated condition that has only raised IgA or IgE

 

Option C - Clinical features of classical lymphatic filariasis (Bancroftian filariasis):

  •  
  • Lymphangitis
  • Obstruction of lymph nodes
  • Lymph varices
  • Hydrocele
  • Elephantiasis
  • Chyluria

Option D – Loeffler’s pneumonia is a hypersensitivity reaction caused by Ascaris lumbricoides.

 

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No 416.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease (stage 3) undergoes a total knee replacement. Postoperatively, he reports significant pain around the surgical site. His medical history includes hypertension, controlled with lisinopril, and type 2 diabetes, managed with metformin. He is allergic to codeine. His current renal function is stable, with a creatinine clearance of 45 mL/min. The patient's surgical and anesthesia teams are considering the best analgesic options for him. Which of the following is the most appropriate postoperative analgesic regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Oral acetaminophen

 

Explanation:

  • Oral acetaminophen (Answer D): Acetaminophen is a safe and effective choice for pain management in patients with chronic kidney disease, especially when renal function is closely monitored. It provides good analgesia for mild to moderate pain and has a minimal impact on renal function compared to NSAIDs and opioids.
  • Intravenous morphine (Answer A): While morphine is effective for severe pain, it should be used cautiously in patients with CKD due to the risk of accumulation of morphine metabolites, which can exacerbate renal dysfunction and lead to adverse effects such as respiratory depression.
  • Oral ibuprofen (Answer B) and Intravenous ketorolac (Answer C): Both are NSAIDs, which are generally avoided in patients with CKD due to their potential nephrotoxic effects, including the risk of worsening renal function and fluid retention.

questions.text: A 16y girl is brought to the OPD as she has not started her period. The patients 14y sister underwent menarche 2 years earlier and her mother began menstruating at age 13. She has no weight gain, headaches, nipple discharge or abdominal pain. She is not sexually active and is not using any method of contraception. She is physically active and is on her school’s basketball team. Her breast exam and pubic hair are Tanner stage IV. The abdomen is soft. The external genitalia appear normal. The vagina ends in a blind pouch. An ultrasound reveals ovaries, but no cervix or uterus is seen. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mullerian agenesis

  • Mullerian agenesis is also known as MRKH syndrome
  • There is no Mullerian structure (Absent uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes, upper 2/3rd of vagina) but ovaries are present
  • So patient presents as primary amenorrhoea with normal secondary sexual characters
  • All hormonal levels are normal
  • Skeletal and renal anomalies may be associated
  • Karyotype: 46XX
  • Treatment
    • Fertility: Surrogacy, uterine transplant (upcoming)
    • Sexual: Vaginoplasty

 

Ref: Speroff’s 9th edition chapter 10, amenorrhea

questions.text: Viral infection causing transient aplastic anemia is:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Parvovirus B-19

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the otolaryngology clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in the right side of his face. Upon examination, the physician noted swelling in the parotid gland. The patient also reported that his symptoms worsened when he ate food, and he had lost his appetite due to the discomfort. The physician ordered an ultrasound imaging of the salivary glands, which revealed the presence of lesions as shown in his parotid gland. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sialolithiasis

  • Sialolithiasis is a condition where a stone or calculus forms within a salivary gland or duct.
  • The condition is most commonly found in the submandibular gland, but can also occur in the parotid gland and other salivary glands.

Sialolithiasis can cause symptoms such as pain, swelling, and tenderness in the affected gland, difficulty opening the mouth, and dry mouth especially during eating when salivary secretion increases (Meal time syndrome). The stones themselves can sometimes be palpated and can be seen on imaging studies like ultrasound, which might display hypoechoic (darker) areas representing the stones.

  • Let’s look at the other options :

 

Option B. Foreign body

 

A foreign body in the context of the parotid gland could refer to any external object that has somehow made its way into the gland or its duct. It's an uncommon occurrence for a foreign body to be located in the salivary glands. Typically, if someone were to suspect a foreign body, there would likely be a history of trauma or an incident where the foreign object could have entered the gland.

 

Option C. Pleomorphic adenoma: Though this is the commonest parotid swelling, it would present as a painless mass, unrelated to meals.

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy

 

Cervical lymphadenopathy refers to the enlargement of lymph nodes in the cervical (neck) region. Enlarged lymph nodes can be due to various causes, including infections, inflammatory conditions, or malignancies. While they can be present near the parotid gland, they are distinct from it. Swelling of the lymph nodes wouldn't typically cause pain that worsens during eating, as described in the patient's symptoms.

 

Given the symptoms described, especially the pain that worsens with eating, and the ultrasound findings, Sialolithiasis (option A) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

choices.text: Spironolactone is a potassium sparing drug.
Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic.
Thiazides act by inhibiting Na-K-2Cl co-transporter.
Acetazolamide inhibits carbonic anhydrase enzyme.

questions.text: All the following are true regarding diuretics except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thiazides act by inhibiting Na-K-2Cl co-transporter.

 

Na-K-2Cl transporter is present in ascending limb of loop of Henle and is inhibited by loop diuretics like furosemide. Thiazides act by inhibiting Na-Cl transporter in early distal tubules.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reflex,  light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

The above patient presents with features suggesting an involvement of the trigeminal nerve. The structure marked 3 is the trigeminal nerve

 

The various clinical features associated with trigeminal nerve injury are:

  1. Facial pain: Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by severe facial pain, often described as sharp, stabbing, or electric shock-like sensations. The pain is typically triggered by routine activities such as eating, talking, or touching specific areas of the face.
  2. Sensory abnormalities: The trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from the face, including touch, temperature, and pain. When affected, sensory abnormalities may manifest as numbness, tingling, or altered sensation in the face. The distribution of these sensory disturbances depends on which branches of the trigeminal nerve are involved.
  3. Facial muscle weakness: The trigeminal nerve also supplies motor fibers to the muscles involved in chewing, such as the muscles of mastication. In certain conditions, such as trigeminal neuropathy or facial nerve palsy involving the trigeminal nerve, weakness or paralysis of these muscles can occur, leading to difficulty in chewing and controlling facial expressions.
  4. Corneal reflex abnormalities: The ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for the corneal reflex, which involves blinking in response to corneal stimulation. Disorders affecting the trigeminal nerve may result in a diminished or absent corneal reflex on the affected side.
  5. Headache: Some disorders involving the trigeminal nerve, such as trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (e.g., cluster headaches), can cause severe headaches on one side of the head. These headaches often occur in close proximity to the trigeminal nerve distribution.

 

Other marked structures:

  • 1- Optic nerve
  • 2- Abducent nerve
  • 4- Vestibulo cochlear nerve

Let’s discuss all the marked structures:

 

Option A. Optic Nerve (II):

  • The optic nerve is responsible for transmitting visual information from the retina to the brain.
  • It is purely sensory in function. It begins at the retina, passes through the optic canal of the sphenoid bone, and joins the optic nerve of the opposite side at the optic chiasm.
  • At this junction, fibers from the nasal half of each retina cross over. 
  • Damage to the optic nerve can result in vision loss. Glaucoma, a condition with increased intraocular pressure, can damage the optic nerve and lead to blindness.

Option B. Abducent Nerve (VI) :

  • This nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye (moves it laterally).
  • It originates in the pons of the brainstem and travels through the superior orbital fissure to reach the orbit.
  •  Damage to this nerve can result in an inability to abduct the affected eye, leading to a condition called lateral rectus palsy.
  • This can manifest as double vision (diplopia) when looking to the side.

Option C. Trigeminal Nerve (V) :

  • It is the largest cranial nerve and has both sensory and motor functions.
  • Sensory functions include facial sensation, and the motor function is mainly for muscles of mastication (chewing).
  •  It has three main branches: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3).
  • The nerve originates in the pons and exits the brainstem to innervate its various targets. 
  • Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition where there's intense, stabbing pain along the path of the nerve. It's considered one of the most painful conditions in medicine.

Option D. Vestibulocochlear Nerve (VIII) :

  • It has two parts: the cochlear nerve (for hearing) and the vestibular nerve (for balance).
  • It originates in the inner ear and enters the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle.
  • Damage can lead to issues like sensorineural hearing loss or balance disorders like vertigo.

questions.text: Veena, a 28-year-old marketing executive, frequently finds herself in intense but unstable relationships. She recalls falling deeply in love with multiple partners in the past, but these relationships often ended abruptly due to explosive arguments. Veena has a history of alternating between idealizing her partners and then suddenly feeling like they are entirely wrong for her. She struggles with a persistent fear of abandonment and has made impulsive decisions in attempts to avoid being alone, including getting tattoos, changing jobs, and relocating. Veena 's mood can shift rapidly, and she has a history of self-harming behaviors, especially after confrontations with her partners. Recently, Veena sought therapy because she recognized a pattern and wants to understand herself better. Based on the above scenario, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for Veena?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Borderline Personality Disorder

 

Explanation of each option:

 

OPTION C: Borderline Personality Disorder:

  • The description of Vanessa's intense but unstable relationships, rapid mood shifts, fear of abandonment, impulsive decisions, self-harming behaviors, and idealization followed by devaluation of partners are characteristic of Borderline Personality Disorder. Individuals with BPD often struggle with unstable self-identity and interpersonal relationships.

OPTION A: Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder:

  • Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder involves a preoccupation with orderliness, perfectionism, and control. Individuals with this disorder are often focused on rules and details, which is not characteristic of Vanessa's impulsive and unstable relationships and mood shifts.

OPTION B: Narcissistic Personality Disorder:

  • Narcissistic Personality Disorder is characterized by an exaggerated sense of self-importance, a need for admiration, and a lack of empathy for others. While Vanessa may experience intense emotions and impulsivity, the central features of narcissism, such as grandiosity and a lack of empathy, are not highlighted in the scenario.

OPTION D: Schizotypal Personality Disorder:

  • Schizotypal Personality Disorder involves eccentric behavior, odd beliefs or magical thinking, and difficulties with interpersonal relationships. While Vanessa does exhibit some impulsive behavior and mood swings, her symptoms are not indicative of schizotypal traits.

 

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE :

 

Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) is a complex mental health disorder characterized by patterns of varying moods, self-image, and behavior. These patterns often result in impulsive actions and problems in relationships. People with BPD may experience intense episodes of anger, depression, and anxiety that last a few hours to a few days.

 

Symptoms: BPD is associated with several signs and symptoms, including:

  1. Fear of Abandonment: Individuals with BPD often fear being abandoned or left alone. Even something as innocuous as a loved one arriving home late can trigger an intense fear.
  2. Unstable Relationships: Relationships may be characterized by extreme swings from intense closeness and love to deep disdain or anger.
  3. Unclear or Shifting Self-Image: Individuals might view themselves as evil or bad and may feel as if they don't exist at all. This unstable self-concept can lead to frequent shifts in jobs, friendships, goals, and values.
  4. Impulsive Behaviors: This can include things like excessive spending, unsafe driving, substance abuse, or risky sexual behavior.
  5. Self-Harming Behaviors: Suicidal threats or behavior or self-harm, such as cutting, are common.
  6. Mood Swings: Periods of intense depression, irritability, or anxiety lasting a few hours to a few days.

questions.text: The floods had an impact on Kerala's Pathanamthitta district, leading the government to provide doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. What other chemical is set to be distributed in conjunction with this?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Zinc phosphide

  • The government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis following floods in Kerala to prevent the spread of diseases such as leptospirosis, acute diarrheal diseases, and dengue.
  • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system.
  • Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness
  • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water.
  • General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.

Filariform larvae of Necator americanus

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient living with HIV and AIDS presented with breathlessness and fever. CXR revealed bronchopneumonia and stool examination revealed the following finding. What is the finding seen in the stool?
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  Rhabditiform larvae of S.stercoralis

 

The clinical features of pneumonia in an immunosuppressed host are suggestive of Strongyloides stercoralis.

  • Infective form  is filariform larvae which enters by skin penetration and then migrates through capillaries, lungs , causing pneumonitis, bronchopneumonia, eosinophiliA. 
  • Two important manifestations seen in immunocompromised (AIDS) patients are:
    • Hyper infection syndrome
    • Disseminated strongyloidiasis.

The laboratory diagnosis of Strongyloidiasis is by demonstration of rhabditiform larvae from the stool. When eggs are hatching out in the stool, it immediately forms rhabditiform larvae and visualized in stool samples.

 

Other options – Option C and D are infective stages of hookworms and not seen directly in the stool sample.

 

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No 594.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the medical OPD with cheilosis, desquamation and inflammation of the tongue, and seborrheic dermatitis. The doctor suggested a medical test and her erythrocyte glutathione reductase was found to be reduced in the results. Which of the following vitamins is deficient in the patient ?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vitamin B2

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms and the reduced erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity suggest a deficiency of Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin). Riboflavin is crucial for various metabolic pathways, and its deficiency can manifest as cheilosis, inflammation of the tongue, and seborrheic dermatitis.

 

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

 

A. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with pernicious anemia and neurological symptoms, but it does not typically present with the specific symptoms described in the case.

 

B. Vitamin B1: Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency leads to beriberi, which primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems. The symptoms described are not characteristic of thiamine deficiency.

 

C. Vitamin B6: While vitamin B6 deficiency can cause dermatitis, it does not usually lead to the specific combination of symptoms mentioned in the case.

questions.text: A 29-year woman presents to the Gyn OPD with her husband. She has been unsuccessfully trying to conceive since 1.5 years. On asking, she reveals that she has irregular menstrual cycles. There is no other significant history. Which of the following is NOT a test for determining if she is ovulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Urinary FSH

 

Explanation

 

Tests for Ovulation include

  1. History: Regular menstrual cycles; Mittelschmerz, dysmenorrhoea, Premenstrual Syndrome
  2. Basal body temperature: Just prior to ovulation, there is a drop in temperature by 0.25, then it rises by 0.5 deg C
  3. Cervical mucus study: At the time of ovulation, cervical mucus is thin and stretchy; It is thin and viscous at the time of luteal phase 
  4. Hormonal Studies:
    1. Mid Luteal Progesterone: Peak on Day 21 (> 10 ng/ml)
    2. Urinary LH kits 
  5. Endometrial Biopsy (Secretory phase of the cycle at day 21)
  6. Ultrasound:
  • Trilaminar endometrium seen in the proliferative phase.
  • In the secretory phase, the endometrium becomes homogeneous.
  • Ovary: Shows a dominant follicle at the time of ovulation (!8-20 mm)
  1. Laparoscopy: If performed mid-cycle, a large follicle may be seen

 

 

Ref: Page 435, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of double vision and drooping eyelids, which worsen towards the evening. She also reports difficulty in chewing and swallowing, especially during meals. Her symptoms have progressively worsened over the past few months. On examination, she shows marked ptosis and diplopia, which improve after a rest period. Based on the clinical presentation and diagnostic findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Myasthenia Gravis

 

Explanation:

  • Myasthenia Gravis (Answer B): This autoimmune disorder is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that typically worsens with activity and improves with rest. The patient’s symptoms of double vision (diplopia) and drooping eyelids (ptosis) that worsen as the day progresses are classic presentations of myasthenia gravis. The improvement in symptoms after rest is also a key feature of this condition. Myasthenia gravis occurs due to the production of antibodies that interfere with the transmission of signals from the nerves to the muscles at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Multiple Sclerosis (Answer A): While MS can cause visual disturbances and neurological symptoms, it typically presents with other signs and symptoms related to central nervous system demyelination and doesn't characteristically show the improvement with rest seen in myasthenia gravis.
  • Guillain-Barré Syndrome (Answer C): This condition usually presents as a rapidly progressive muscle weakness starting from the lower limbs and moving upwards. It is an acute demyelinating disorder affecting the peripheral nervous system and doesn't typically manifest with the fluctuating weakness of ocular muscles as seen in myasthenia gravis.
  • Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (Answer D): ALS, a progressive neurodegenerative disease affecting nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, presents with both upper and lower motor neuron signs and leads to progressive muscle weakness. Unlike myasthenia gravis, ALS symptoms do not fluctuate throughout the day and don’t improve with rest.

questions.text: A male patient presented with anaemia, bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly. The trephine biopsy of bone marrow is taken and the result is shown below. What is the enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Glucocerebrosidase

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows crumpled tissue paper appearance of macrophage cells which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. This disease is a type of sphingolipidoses and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme β-glucosyl ceramidase. This deficiency results in the accumulation of a fatty substance called glucosylceramide in cells, particularly in macrophages.

 

Symptoms: Common symptoms include bone pain, anemia, enlarged organs (spleen and liver), a swollen and painful abdomen, and easy bruising. The severity of symptoms can vary.

 

Inheritance: Gaucher's disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning that both parents must carry a mutated GBA1 gene for a child to inherit the disease

questions.text: A 55-year-old male who is a diagnosed case of multiple myeloma has come up for follow-up. Which of the following is a poor prognostic factor; if increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Beta 2 microglobulin

  • Serum β 2 -microglobulin is the sin­gle most powerful predictor of survival and can substitute for staging.
  • High levels of β 2 microglobulin is associated with poor prognosis in a patient with multiple myeloma.

questions.text:
The type(s) of afferent nerve fibers in the muscle spindle are?

  1. II
  2. III
  3. Ia
  4. Ib
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1,3

  • The extrafusal muscle fibers are the major contractile units involved in muscle contraction and the intrafusal muscle fibers (muscle spindle) are located parallel to these extrafusal fibers
  • Group Ia and group II afferent fibers are associated with the muscle spindle, whereas group Ib fibers are associated with Golgi tendon organ
  • The muscle spindle senses the changes in muscle length, whereas the Golgi tendon organ senses the changes in muscle tension

 

(Refer: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 95)

questions.text: What sample is required to diagnose the organism shown in this test slide?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gastric mucosa

 

This is a rapid urease test done for diagnosis of H. Pylori gastritis from antral mucosal biopsy.

  • One of the characteristics of H. pylori is its ability to hydrolyse urea, resulting in the production of ammonia, a strong alkali. The effect of ammonia on the antral G cells is to cause release of gastrin via negative feedback that is responsible for the modest, but inappropriate, hypergastrinemia in patients with peptic ulcer disease which, in turn, may result in gastric acid hypersecretion.
  • The organism’s obligate urease activity is utilized by various tests used to detect the presence of the organism, including the 13C and 14C breath tests and the CLO test (a commercially available urease test kit), which is performed on gastric antral biopsies.
  • The organism can also be detected histologically using the Giemsa or the Warthin–Starry silver stains, and cultured using appropriate media. Previous or current infection with the organism may also be detected serologically. Breath tests or fecal antigen tests are recommended for the pretreatment diagnosis of H. pylori infection in the community. Less accurate, hospital-based serology tests have a place within a non-invasive test-and-treat strategy.

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Edition, page 1155.

choices.text: Will be associated with curdy white discharge
Fluconazole is the treatment of choice

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to OPD with complaint of discharge per vagina associated with intense itching. Wet mount of vaginal secretions is shown below. Which of the following is TRUE:
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Associated with strawberry cervix

  • Flagellated motile trichomonads are shown in the picture: This patient has trichomonas vaginitis
  • Trichomonas vaginitis
    • Caused by flagellated parasite, Trichomonas vaginalis
    • Associated with profuse frothy, greenish, malodorous discharge
    • Associated with intense vulvar pruritis
    • Patchy vaginal erythema or colpitis macularis (strawberry cervix) may be present
    • Pregnant women with trichomonas are at increased risk of PROM and preterm labor
    • Treatment is with metronidazole and tinidazole
    • Kit 2 is used (green kit)

 

Ref: Berek & novak 16ed, page 885

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prozone phenomenon

 

The initial negative test is explained by the prozone phenomenon. The standard agglutination test is a tube agglutination test that mainly identifies IgM antibodies. It is used in establishing a diagnosis of acute brucellosis.

 

Prozone phenomenon refers to the failure of a visible precipitation reaction due to inhibition of lattice formation by the presence of excessive antibodies. This gives rise to a false-negative test. This excess in antibodies can be overcome by diluting the serum sample, leading to an increase in the antigen-antibody interactions, eventually giving rise to a positive result.

 

Lattice hypothesis:

 

The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies.

  • Prozone phenomenon: Caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent precipitation-false-negative test)
  • Zone of equivalence: Antigens and antibodies are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs.
  • Post-zone phenomenon: (Option-D) Due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. (weaker/absent precipitation)

questions.text: During a public health lecture, the instructor discusses various concepts of disability and health. One student asks for clarification regarding the general term used to describe any restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity within the range considered normal for a human. How is this condition generally defined?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Disability

 

Explanation - A disability is defined as "any restriction or lack (resulting from an impairment) of ability to perform an activity in manner or within the range considered normal for a human being".

 

Disease-Impairment-Disability-Handicap

  • Disease: Any abnormal condition of an organism that impairs function
  • Impairment: Any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological, or anatomical structure or function
  • Disability: (Because of impairment,) any restriction or inability to perform an activity in a range considered normal for a human being
  • Handicap: A disadvantage for a given

individual, resulting from an impairment/ disability, that limits/prevents the fulfillment of a role considered normal (depending on age, sex, social, and cultural factors) for that individual

 

Reference: Park 26th edition (page 668)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with a history of alcohol use disorder presents to your clinic for treatment. He has a long history of heavy drinking and has recently stopped drinking. Which of the following medications is commonly used to prevent relapse in patients with alcohol use disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Naltrexone.

  • Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist medication that is used to treat alcohol use disorder by reducing the craving for alcohol and preventing relapse in individuals who have stopped drinking. It works by blocking the effects of endorphins, which are naturally occurring chemicals in the brain that are released in response to alcohol consumption.
  • Methadone is an opioid agonist medication that is primarily used to treat opioid addiction by reducing withdrawal symptoms and cravings.
  • Naloxone and nalmefene are also opioid antagonist medications, but they are primarily used to reverse opioid overdose and are not typically used in the treatment of alcohol use disorder.

choices.text: ANCA for diagnosis of vasculitis
Biopsy to rule out squamous cell cancer of lung

questions.text: A patient presented with history of chronic sinusitis and ulcerative lesions in the nasopharynx. He also had nodular lesions and cavitation in the lungs and features of renal failure. What is the most important investigation useful for diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. ANCA for diagnosis of vasculitis

 

Likely diagnosis is Wegener granulomatosis (remember RULe of Wegener granulomatosis). So, it is associated with c-ANCA. Churg Strauss and microscopic polyangiitis have p-ANCA.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a 30-pack-year smoking history presents to his primary care physician complaining of a chronic productive cough, shortness of breath, and frequent wheezing. These symptoms have progressively worsened over the last three years. He also reports a recent exacerbation with increased sputum production. His physical examination reveals a prolonged expiratory phase and diffuse wheezing on auscultation. Spirometry testing shows an FEV1 in 1 second of 1.2 L (50% of predicted) and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.60 post-bronchodilator. His chest X-ray indicates hyperinflation of the lungs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)

 

Explanation:

  • Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) (Answer B): The patient's history of long-term smoking, symptoms of chronic productive cough, shortness of breath, and wheezing, along with the spirometry findings (FEV1/FVC ratio < 0.70 post-bronchodilator and reduced FEV1), are indicative of COPD. The chest X-ray showing lung hyperinflation further supports this diagnosis. COPD is characterized by persistent respiratory symptoms and airflow limitation due to airway and/or alveolar abnormalities, typically caused by significant exposure to harmful particles or gases.
  • Asthma (Answer A): Asthma is also characterized by symptoms such as wheezing and shortness of breath. However, asthma usually presents with variable and often reversible airflow obstruction, and its onset is often earlier in life.
  • Pulmonary Fibrosis (Answer C): Pulmonary fibrosis typically presents with a restrictive pattern on spirometry (reduced FVC with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio), which is not seen in this patient.

questions.text: With endometriosis, as shown here, which of the following is ectopically located?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Endometrial glands and stroma

 

Explanation

  • Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (including glands and stroma) outside the uterus.

 

Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: History of similar illness in the past
History of diet

questions.text: A man from Chhattisgarh presented with a gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms in his legs. Upon examination, he exhibited a specific loss of motor function. What inquiries should be made to gather the most relevant medical history from this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. History of diet

  • The clinical presentation suggests that the patient may have neurolathyrism, which is caused by the excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal.
  • To confirm the diagnosis, it is important to obtain the patient's dietary history.
  • Neurolathyrism is a paralytic condition caused by the consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal, which is common in certain regions of India such as Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and Bihar.
  • The disease mainly affects the nervous system, causing gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. It primarily affects males between the ages of 15 and 45 years and progresses through several stages.
  • The toxin responsible for the disease is BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine), which is water-soluble and can be removed from the pulses by soaking them in hot water and discarding the water.
  • Large-scale detoxification can be achieved by parboiling the crop, or by overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling.
  • Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can help prevent and treat lathyrism.
  • In India, the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act prohibits the use of Lathyrus sativus in any form (whole/split/flour).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman complains of fatigue, weight gain, and increased sensitivity to cold. On physical examination, she has noticeable swelling in her neck. Additionally, an ultrasound examination shows that her thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and has an uneven texture. The histological image is shown below. Which of the following conditions is most likely the cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis
 

The given findings are suggestive of diffuse goitre with clinical hypothyroidism, suggestive of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis/ Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis.

 

Option A. Medullary carcinoma:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma originates from parafollicular C cells in the thyroid gland. These cells produce calcitonin, and the carcinoma often increases levels of this hormone. The tumor can appear as a firm mass in the neck. Histologically, it contains nests or sheets of cells in an amyloid stroma. It doesn't show the typical lymphocytic infiltration seen in Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Clinical hypothyroidism is not a feature.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma:

Rarely, the thyroid gland can be affected by primary thyroid lymphoma, which often arises in the setting of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. However, it would be differentiated by its histological appearance, with large numbers of lymphoid cells but lacking the characteristic features of Hashimoto's, such as Hurthle cells. Hypothyroidism is not a feature.

 

Option C. Grave's disease:

Grave's disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies stimulate the thyroid gland, leading to overproduction of thyroid hormones. Symptoms might include weight loss, increased heart rate, tremors, and exophthalmos (bulging eyes). The histology of Grave's disease is characterized by tall, columnar epithelial cells and scalloped colloid, which is different from the described histological findings.

 

Option D. Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

Hashimoto's thyroiditis, also known as chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, is an autoimmune disorder that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland. Patients often present with hypothyroidism symptoms, such as fatigue, weight gain, and cold sensitivity. As for the histological findings, Hashimoto's thyroiditis is characterized by:

  1. Lymphocytic infiltration with germinal centers.
  2. Follicular cell damage.
  3. Reduced colloid and increased fibrous tissue.
  4. Presence of Hurthle cells (or Askanazy cells) which are oxyphilic cells with a granular cytoplasm.

questions.text: Most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Granisetron

 

Granisetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist that is highly effective for preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). These drugs have become the standard of care for managing moderate to highly emetogenic chemotherapy agents.

 

Explanation of All Other Options:

 

A. Domperidone: Domperidone is a dopamine receptor antagonist used for the treatment of nausea and vomiting, but it is generally not as effective as 5-HT3 receptor antagonists like Granisetron for managing chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

 

B. Tegaserod: Tegaserod is primarily used for treating irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with constipation and is not an antiemetic. It acts as a 5-HT4 receptor agonist to promote gastrointestinal motility.

 

D. Doxylamine: Doxylamine is an antihistamine that can be used for nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, often in combination with pyridoxine (vitamin B6). It is not the most effective option for chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

 

Therefore, the most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is Granisetron, making option C the correct answer.

questions.text: Michaelis Gutmann bodies are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Malacoplakia (Ref: Robbins 10th 956)

  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are laminated mineralized concretions typically present within the macrophages resulting from deposition of calcium in enlarged lys­osomes. It is seen in malacoplakia. Similar lesions are also seen in the colon, lungs, bones, kidneys, prostate, and epididymis. In this conditions, there is presence of PAS+ macrophages.

questions.text: Pasteurization is done at?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 63 degree Celsius for 30 minutes

 

Pasteurization: Milk is heated at either

  • 63°C for 30 minutes: the Holder method or
  • 72°C for 15-20 seconds: the flash process

followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

 

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in Holder method.

questions.text: What is the proper disposal method for a damaged vaccine vial according to biomedical waste management protocols?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Puncture proof blue bin 

 

Blue puncture proof container

 

Under BMW guidelines, Glassware and Metallic Body Implants are disposed in Cardboard boxes with blue colored marking.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is tested positive for HIV. He presented to OPD with complaints of persistent cough, weight loss and skin lesions on face, trunk and upper extremities. He was tested for Tuberculosis which came negative. Chest X-ray was done and revealed bilateral nodular infiltrates. CD4 count is 100 cells/mL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HIV with disseminated Histoplasmosis

 

Most HIV positive patients with low CD4 count present with disseminated histoplasmosis.

 

Common clinical manifestations include fever, fatigue, malaise, anorexia, weight loss, and respiratory symptoms. 

 

Physical examination frequently reveals lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and/or splenomegaly, with skin and oral lesions less common.

 

Laboratory tests usually show anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated bilirubin and hepatic enzymes.

 

Pulmonary imaging is characterized by diffuse reticulonodular, interstitial, or miliary infiltrates.

 

The gold standard for the diagnosis of histoplasmosis is culture. Antigen also may be detected in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BAL) and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

 

Treatment - Liposomal amphotericin B should be used in patients who are sufficiently ill to require hospitalization. Once the patient improves, can be transitioned to Itraconazole.

 

Ruling out other options:

 

Option A) Cryptococcosis causes meningitis in most cases of HIV patients

 

Option C) Molluscum contagiosum doesn’t involve Lung

 

Option D) Tuberculosis test results came negative

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with organophosphate poisoning. He was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime. After 2 hours, the patient had a sudden rise in temperature. What is the likely cause of fever?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Atropine toxicity

 

The most likely cause of fever in this patient is atropine toxicity.

 

The clinical scenario is of organophosphate poisoning and patient was started on atropine infusion and pralidoxime.

 

Atropine is a non-specific muscarinic receptor blocker, but not the nicotinic effects.

A/E of Atropine include –

  • ↑body temperature (due to ↓sweating)
  • ↑ HR
  • Dry mouth, Dry & flushed skin
  • Cycloplegia
  • Constipation
  • Disorientation
  • Can cause acute angle-closure glaucoma in older adults (due to mydriasis)
  • Urinary retention in men with prostatic hyperplasia
  • Hyperthermia in infants

Pralidoxime is given as an adjuvant to atropine in cases of organophosphate poisoning. It does not increase body temperature.

 

Hence, the sudden rise in body temperature is most likely attributed to Atropine Toxicity.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Facial nerve

 

The given clinical features of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth are suggestive of paralysis of the facial nerve.

 

Bell's palsy is defined as idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset.

 

Etiology –

Viral infection  - herpes simplex, herpes zoster, EBV

Vascular ischemia

Heredity – narrow fallopian canal

Autoimmune

 

Clinical features -

 

Onset is sudden. Patient is unable to close his eyes. On attempting to close the eye, the eyeball turns up and out (Bell phenomenon). Saliva dribbles from the angle of mouth. Face becomes asymmetrical. Tears flow down from the eye (epiphora). Pain in the ear may precede or accompany nerve paralysis. Some complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani). Paralysis may be complete or incomplete. Bell palsy is recurrent in 3–10% of patients.

 

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigations.

 

Treatment of Bell's palsy -

 

Prednisolone is the drug of choice. If a patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose of prednisolone is 1 mg/kg/day divided into morning and evening doses for 5 days. Patient is seen on the fifth day. If paralysis is incomplete or is recovering, the dose is tapered during the next 5 days. If paralysis remains complete, the same dose is continued for another 10 days and thereafter tapered in next 5 days (total of 20 days).

 

Eye care to prevent keratitis

Analgesic for ear pain

Physiotherapy

 

 

Reference - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 103, 104

choices.text: Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of Guillain-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy

 

AIDP is the most common type of GBS presenting with ascending motor weakness with occasional distal sensory paresthesia due to demyelination of posterior column.

 

Axonal variants:

  • AMAN (Acute motor axonal neuropathy): GM1a, GD1a    
  • AMSAN (Acute motor & sensory axonal neuropathy): GM1a, GD1a         

 

Other variants

  • Acute motor conduction block neuropathy: GM1a, GD1a
  • Pharyngo-cervico-branchial variant: GT1a
  • Miller-Fischer variant: GQ1b >> GT1a
  • Acute ataxic neuropathy: GQ1b >> GT1a
  • Pure sensory ataxic variant: GD1b
  • Bickerstaff brainstem encephalitis (BBE): GQ1 >> GT1a

 

Reference - Adam and Viktor/Peripheral neuropathy/GBS page 1322

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with rectal prolapse to the emergency room. On a rectal swab, the following egg was seen. Which of the following infections is associated with rectal prolapse in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Trichiuris trichiura

 

The egg shown in the image has the characteristic findings as given below:

  • Barrel shaped.
  • Bile-stained egg.
  • Mucous plugs at both ends – which are not bile stained.
  • Trichuris trichiura has a characteristic whip-like shape and hence it is called Whipworm.
  • It usually affects children and remains asymptomatic.
  • Heavy infection causes rectal prolapse in children  and appendicitis.

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No 508.

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG revealed large T-waves. Laboratory tests revealed elevated potassium levels. Which of the following drugs can cause intracellular movement of potassium?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Epinephrine

 

Beta 2 agonists (like Salbutamol and Epinephrine) and Insulin help in the intracellular movement of K+. These drugs therefore can decrease serum potassium levels.

 

The drugs that can be used in the management of acute hyperkalemia are as follows:

  • Salbutamol
  • Glucose + Insulin (DOC)
  • Calcium gluconate

In case of chronic hyperkalemia, K+ binding resins like Patiromer and Polystyrene sulfonate can be used.

questions.text: ANCA is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Wegener's granulomatosis

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/514)

Interferons are used for treatment

questions.text: The following are true attributes of hepatitis B infection except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HBc Ag in serum is indicative of active infection (Ref: Robbins 10th 833)

  • HBe Ag and not HBc Ag in serum is indicative of active infection.
  • Persistence of HBeAg is an important indicator of continued viral replication, infectivity, and probable progression to chronic hepatitis.

choices.text: Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout
Hyperventilation causing increased CO2 washout
Increased tubular reabsorption of HCO3-

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis findings of a patient are as follows. pH= 7.30, HCO3= 10 mEq/L, paco2= 30 mmHg, which is suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. What is the mechanism for the secondary disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout

 

ABG shows pH 7.3 (acidosis) → Metabolic (HCO3- = 10)

 

Expected pCO2 = HCO3 +15 = 25 is < actual pCO2 (30) suggesting there is excess CO2 than expected. Hypoventilation leads to CO2 accumulation.

 

Other options:

  • Option B - Hyperventilation leads to excess CO2 washout and would have reduced the pCO2 levels than the expected values.
  • Option C - Increased absorption of HCO3 will lead to metabolic alkalosis.
  • Option D - Increased H+ excretion will lead to metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E. coli species from E. coli 0157: H7?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sorbitol MacConkey agar

 

E.coli 0157: H7 can be differentiated from other E.coli species using sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

There are more than 150 serotypes of Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli (STEC). Of these, 0157:7 is the most common type. Unlike most other E.Coli serotypes, the STEC 0157:H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

0157: H7 strains also are negative for -glucuronidase using the substrate 4-methylumbelliferyl-B-glucuronide test. More than 90 per cent of other E. coli tests positive with this substrate.

choices.text: Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg HS for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 500 mcg one tablet OD for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam ½ mg tablet HS daily

questions.text: As an Indian medical intern, which of the following is the correct format for prescription of alprazolam?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days

 

IMPORTANT POINTS REGARDING PRESCRIPTION WRITING:

  • Prescription is invalid without date and signature of the doctor.
  • Drug name should never been written in abbreviation form (e.g. never write PCM for paracetamol).
  • Abbreviations like OD, BD, HS etc should not be used in prescription.
  • Leading zeros should always be mentioned (e.g. 0.5 mg is correct but .5 mg is incorrect)
  • Trail zeros should never be written (e.g. 5 mg is correct but 5.0 is incorrect).
  • Microgram should be written as mcg not as µg.

choices.text: Artesunate + Sulfadoxine + pyrimethamine

questions.text: Dr. Lalnunmawia, an experienced physician at Civil Hospital Aizawl, is assessing a 35-year-old farmer from the hills of Mizoram. The patient complains of episodic intense fever accompanied by shaking chills for the past week. On examination, the patient's spleen is palpably enlarged. Blood investigations reveal the presence of P. falciparum trophozoites. Keeping in mind the unique topography, climatic conditions, and malaria resistance profiles known to Mizoram, Dr. Lalnunmawia needs to decide the most effective antimalarial regimen to initiate. Which of the following treatments should he prescribe as the first-line ?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Artemether + lumefantrine

 

Explanation - 

 

The most appropriate treatment for Plasmodium falciparum infection in North Eastern states is artemether + lumefantrine

 

ARTEMISINS - ARTESUNATE AND ARTEMETHER

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 Artemisin Combination Therapy [ACT]

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only)

choices.text: Diminished calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: Mechanism of muscle weakness in Lambert-Eaton syndrome is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Antibody against presynaptic channels at the nerve-muscle junction  (Ref Robbins 10th 1226)

  • The clinical scenario, weakness in the proximal muscle groups, associated with a pulmonary neoplasm with metastases, is consistent with Lambert-Eaton syndrome associated with small-cell carcinoma. In Lambert-Eaton syndrome, the tumor causes the production of an antibody directed against the presynaptic calcium channels.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department by her grandmother Which of the following is correct about the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kwashiorkor due to less protein intake

 

Explanation - 

 

The given image is suggestive of kwashiorkor, as it shows a bulging abdomen and pedal edema along with thin limbs and prominent ribs. Kwashiorkor occurs as a result of less protein intake, whereas marasmus occurs due to less calorie intake.

questions.text: Inability to initiate or maintain the sexual arousal pattern in females is called as:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Frigidity

 

Frigidity - Inability to initiate or maintain the sexual arousal pattern in females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Satyriasis- Morbid, insatiable sexual need or desire in a man.

 

Option C: Sterility- Inability to procreate children

 

Option D: Nymphomania- Abnormal, excessive, insatiable desire in a woman for sexual intercourse.

A male patient presented with the features shown in figure. Which could be the causative agent?

  2. Metronidazole

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back, nausea, and vomiting that started several hours ago after a heavy alcohol intake. His past medical history is significant for episodes of similar pain, but less intense, and chronic alcohol use. On examination, his abdomen is tender in the epigastric region. Vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, heart rate 98 bpm, and temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F). Laboratory tests reveal a lipase level of 1732 U/L (normal range: 0-160 U/L) and normal liver function tests. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Acute Pancreatitis

 

Explanation:

  • Acute Pancreatitis (Answer B): The patient's presentation of severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, nausea, vomiting, and particularly the significantly elevated lipase level (1732 U/L) are highly indicative of acute pancreatitis. Alcohol abuse is a common risk factor for acute pancreatitis, and lipase is a key enzyme elevated in this condition.
  • Acute Cholecystitis (Answer A): While acute cholecystitis can present with abdominal pain and nausea, it is typically associated with right upper quadrant pain, not epigastric pain radiating to the back, and does not cause such a marked elevation in lipase.
  • Peptic Ulcer Disease (Answer C): Peptic ulcer disease can cause epigastric pain and nausea but typically does not lead to a significant elevation in lipase levels.
  • Hepatic Steatosis (Answer D): Also known as fatty liver disease, hepatic steatosis might be associated with chronic alcohol use but typically presents with elevated liver enzymes, not an elevated lipase level.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male had fever for the past 1 week with abdominal distention and loss of appetite. It is not responding to antibiotics and antimalarials. Widal test is negative but RK39 dipstick test is positive. Which of the following drugs can be used in the above patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Liposomal amphotericin B

  • The given symptoms and test results suggest the possibility of visceral leishmaniasis (also known as kala-azar), which is a parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania donovani complex.
  • Out of the options given, the drug that can be used in the above patient is liposomal amphotericin B, which is the recommended first-line treatment for visceral leishmaniasis. Liposomal amphotericin B is a broad-spectrum antifungal medication that is also effective against various parasitic infections, including leishmaniasis.
  • Bedaquiline and Linezolid are antibiotics that are used to treat bacterial infections, and Fluconazole is an antifungal medication that is used to treat fungal infections. None of these drugs are effective against leishmaniasis.

questions.text: What would be the normal inspiratory reserve volume of the lungs?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 3000 mL

  • The tidal volume can be defined as the volume of air inspired (or expired) during each normal breath
  • The normal tidal volume (TV) in a healthy adult male will be around 500 mL
  • The additional volume of air that can be inspired above the tidal respiration is termed as inspiratory reserve volume.
  • The normal inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) will be around 3000 mL

 

 

(Refer : Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 629)

choices.text: HbsAg and anti Hbe antibody positivity
Mother infected with mutant HBV

questions.text: A 45-day old infant developed icterus and two days later symptoms and signs of acute liver failure appeared. Child was found to be positive for HbsAg. The mother was also HbsAg carrier. The mother's hepatitis B serological profile is likely to be:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. HbsAg and HbeAg positivity

 

Explanation:

  • HbsAg and HbeAg positivity (Answer B): The presence of both Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) in the mother indicates an active HBV infection with high infectivity. HBeAg is a marker of high levels of viral replication and therefore high infectivity. Vertical transmission (from mother to child) of hepatitis B is highly likely when the mother is both HBsAg and HBeAg positive. The infant’s development of acute liver failure is consistent with a high viral load transmission, which is more likely in the setting of maternal HBeAg positivity.
  • HbsAg positive only (Answer A): While being positive for HBsAg indicates that the mother is a carrier of hepatitis B, the absence of HBeAg would suggest a lower level of infectivity. However, this scenario is less consistent with the infant's severe presentation.
  • HbsAg and anti-HBe antibody positivity (Answer C): The presence of anti-HBe antibodies along with HBsAg suggests a lower level of viral replication and hence a lower infectivity compared to the presence of HBeAg. This profile is less likely in a case where vertical transmission has led to acute liver failure in the infant.
  • Mother infected with mutant HBV (Answer D): While mutations in the HBV genome can occur, leading to changes in the expression of HBeAg (e.g., the "precore mutant"), this option does not provide enough specific information to be the most likely answer in this context.

questions.text: A female patient presented with a firm mass of 2 × 2 cms in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. She gives a family history of ovarian carcinoma. The investigation that needs to be done to assess for mutations is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. BRCA2

 

In women with hereditary breast/ovarian cancer, there can be two susceptibility loci:

  • BRCA1 located on chromosome 17q12-21, and
  • BRCA2 located on 13q12-13.

Both these are tumor-suppressor genes which produce nuclear proteins that interact with RAD 51 affecting genomic integrity. The cumulative risk of ovarian cancer with critical mutations of BRCA1 or BRCA2 is 25%. Men in such families have an increased risk of prostate cancer.

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1058

questions.text: Which among the following is the first chemical barrier that is encountered by the microbes in all the tissue fluids EXCEPT CSF?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lysozyme

 

Lysozyme is present in almost all the tissue fluids, more in tears. It is NOT seen in CSF, Sweat and Urine. It splits the polysaccharide component in the cell wall of bacteria thereby helps in innate immunity.

 

Antibacterial substances in human body are as follows:

  • Beta lysin
  • Leukins and plakins
  • Lactic acid
  • Lactoperoxidase in breast milk
  • Interferon

The other options given in the question are examples for acute phase reactants.

 

 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No 177.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with anemia and hemoglobinuria. Investigations reveal increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The peripheral smear image is given below. Which of the following physical examination findings can support the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mechanical second heart sound

 

The above scenario, which includes anemia, increased LDH, and hemoglobinuria, as well as schistocytes on a peripheral smear, is suggestive of macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA). A mechanical second heart sound can help to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a type of hemolytic anemia caused by red cell trauma.

 

Shear forces cause hemolysis in artificial mechanical cardiac valves due to turbulent blood flow and pressure gradients. This traumatic damage causes intravascular hemolysis and the appearance in blood smears of red cell fragments (schistocytes), burr cells, helmet cells, and triangle cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of persistent diarrhea, a gradually worsening rash on his hands and neck, and episodes of memory lapses and confusion. On further questioning, he mentions his primary diet consists of untreated maize (corn) which he consumes in large quantities daily. Given this dietary history and the triad of symptoms, which vitamin deficiency might he be suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Niacin

 

Explanation - 

 

Patient is having features of Pellagra due to deficiency of Vitamin B3 or Niacin.

 

Symptom:

 

4Ds: Dermatitis, dementia, diarrhea, and death

 

Dermatitis is seen around the neck of the person k/a Cassal’s necklace.

 

Consumption of untreated maize as a primary dietary staple is a recognized risk factor for pellagra because maize contains niacin in a form that is not bioavailable unless treated with lime or alkali (a process known as nixtamalization).

questions.text: Cobicistat is used along with which of the following antiretroviral drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Darunavir

  • Cobicistat is a pharmacokinetic enhancer (booster) that is used in combination with certain antiretroviral drugs to increase their effectiveness. It works by inhibiting CYP3A microsomal enzymes that are involved in metabolism of these drugs.
  • Darunavir is a protease inhibitor that is commonly used to treat HIV infection. When used in combination with cobicistat, darunavir's effectiveness is increased due to boosting effect of cobicistat.
  • Elvitegravir is another drug whose effect is boosted by cobicistat. It is an integrase inhibitor.
  • Indinavir, ritonavir, and saquinavir are other protease inhibitors that are used to treat HIV infection, but they are not used in combination with cobicistat. Instead, they are often used in combination with a low dose of ritonavir, which is also a pharmacokinetic enhancer, to increase their effectiveness.

questions.text: Which among the following is an AIDS defining cancer that has been included in WHO clinical staging of HIV/AIDS, Except:

Ans. C. Classical Hodgkin’s lymphoma

 

AIDS associated malignancies

choices.text: Terlipressin is preferred over desmopressin for treatment of bleeding esophageal varices.
Desmopressin is not useful for treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.
Amiloride is used for treatment of lithium induced diabetes insipidus.
Desmopressin can be used for treatment of both pituitary and renal diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: All the following statements are true except.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Desmopressin can be used for treatment of both pituitary and renal diabetes insipidus.

 

Desmopressin

  • It is selective agonist of V2 receptors of vasopressin.
  • Diabetes insipidus (DI) of pituitary origin (neurogenic) is the most important indication for desmopressin.
  • It is ineffective in renal (nephrogenic) Dl since the kidney is unresponsive to ADH.
  • Therefore, desmopressin is the drug of choice for central diabetes insipidus and not much effective against nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.
  • It can be used by intranasal route and oral routes.
  • Clinical Indications:
    • Central diabetes insipidus.
    • Nocturnal enuresis in children.
    • Hemophilia.
    • von Willebrand’s Disease.

In case of esophageal variceal bleeding:

  • Terlipressin ¡s a synthetic analogue of vasopressin with V1 agonistic action. It has longer activity and fewer side effects.
  • It reduces portal pressure and can be used in esophageal variceal bleeding.
  • Desmopressin has shown no clinical benefits ¡n the setting of variceal bleeding.

In case of lithium induced diabetes insipidus:

  • Amiloride is the drug of choice.
  • It blocks entry of Li+ through Na+ channels in the CD cells and mitigates diabetes insipidus induced by lithium.

questions.text: All the following drugs increase bleeding when given to a patient on warfarin except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carbamazepine

 

Carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer and increase the metabolism of warfarin. This will reduce the action of warfarin decreasing the risk of bleeding. All other drugs given in the options increase the risk of bleeding with warfarin.

  • Inducers of CYP2C9 carbamazepine, Phenobarbital and rifampicin increase metabolism of warfarin and hence decrease plasma concentration this can cause thrombosis.
  • Inhibitors of CYP2C9 like isoniazid, amiodarone, cimetidine and cotrimoxazole can inhibit metabolism of warfarin and hence increase plasma concentration; this can cause bleeding.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a 6-month history of increasing fatigue, weight gain primarily around the abdomen, and difficulty sleeping. She also reports her skin has become very thin and bruises easily. On physical examination, she has a rounded face, increased fat deposition in the cervical spine area  and purple striae on her abdomen. Blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg. Laboratory tests show hyperglycemia and hypokalemia. A 24-hour urinary free cortisol test indicates elevated levels of cortisol. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Cushing Syndrome

 

Explanation:

  1. Cushing Syndrome (Answer B): The patient presents with several classic signs and symptoms of Cushing Syndrome. These include:
    • Centripetal obesity: Weight gain primarily around the abdomen.
    • Skin changes: Thin skin that bruises easily and purple striae (stretch marks) are typical manifestations of Cushing Syndrome.
    • Facial changes: A rounded face is often described as a "moon face".
    • Fat deposition: Increased fat in the cervical spine area, known as a ‘buffalo hump’.
    • Hypertension and hyperglycemia: Common consequences of chronic exposure to high levels of cortisol.
    • Elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol: This laboratory finding confirms the presence of excess cortisol, a hallmark of Cushing Syndrome.
       
  2. Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) (Answer A): While PCOS can be associated with obesity and menstrual irregularities, it does not typically present with the specific cushingoid features (such as easy bruising, skin thinning, and purple striae) or elevated cortisol levels.
  3. Adrenal Insufficiency (Answer C): This condition is characterized by a deficiency in cortisol production, which contrasts with the elevated cortisol levels seen in this patient. Adrenal insufficiency typically presents with symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, and low blood pressure.
  4. Primary Aldosteronism (Answer D): This condition typically presents with hypertension and hypokalemia, but it is not associated with the cushingoid features or elevated cortisol levels found in this patient.

The combination of the patient’s clinical presentation and the lab findings (especially the elevated urinary free cortisol) strongly points to Cushing Syndrome.

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the y efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

 

Decerebrate rigidity is the rigid extension of all the limbs due to decerebration. This type of rigidity is well pronounced in the extensor muscles. The term decerebrate rigidity was coined by Sherrington in 1897.

 

Reason for decerebrate rigidity:

  • Release of the centers, situated below the section, from higher inhibitory controls. The inhibitory area is 4S. It is situated in the motor cortex of cerebrum, just anterior to area 4 and behind area 6. In this area, Betz cells are absent.
  • From here, the fibers are projected to spinal cord via reticular formation. So, in decerebration the discharge from neurons of area 4S cannot reach spinal motor neurons. This leads to exaggeration of spinal motor neurons resulting in rigidity.
  • Decerebrate rigidity is also produced by stopping the blood flow to the forebrain. It is done by occlusion of the common carotid artery and the basilar artery at the center of the pons.

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by

  1. γ motor neuron discharge rate increased.
  2. Motor neuron pool excitability increased.
  3. Decerebration produces no phenomenon similar to spinal shock.
  4. Antigravity extensor muscles are involved in decerebrate injury
